reason: User requested a minimal Todo list application and delegated all decisions. Generate a comprehensive requirements analysis report with minimal viable features, user roles, data model, business rules, and APIs suitable for a simple Todo app.

roles.name: user
roles.description: Authenticated end user who manages only their own todo items and account. Can create, read, update, complete, and delete personal tasks. Cannot access or modify other users’ data.

roles.name: admin
roles.description: Administrative user with full authority to oversee the service. Can manage any user account when necessary for support or policy enforcement, access aggregated analytics, enforce content policies, and configure service-wide settings.

files.content:
# todoApp Planning Documentation - Table of Contents

Last updated: 2025-08-15 (KST)

## Document Purpose
Single entry point for all planning artifacts of the todoApp service. Establishes the recommended reading order, provides descriptive links to each document, and aligns stakeholders on navigation across the documentation set. Defines business requirements, user scenarios, and process flows in natural language so backend developers can implement with clarity while retaining full autonomy over technical decisions.

## How to Use This Documentation
- Begin with the service overview to understand vision, scope, and business model. Proceed to roles and authentication to ground access control concepts before diving into the functional scope.
- Follow the reading order below to reduce ambiguity and ensure terms, rules, and flows are interpreted consistently across teams.
- Each link uses the document’s title as link text and points to a relative file in this folder for portability.
- Focus remains on what the system must do from a business perspective. All architectural choices, API designs, and data modeling decisions remain with the development team.

## Table of Contents (with descriptive links)
1. [todoApp Service Overview](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md)
   - Establishes vision, scope, and business model for the minimal Todo service; clarifies value proposition, target users, and success metrics.
2. [todoApp User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md)
   - Defines complete authentication behaviors, role hierarchy, and permissions in business terms; includes session and token management expectations and EARS-formatted access rules.
3. [todoApp Functional Requirements (MVP)](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md)
   - Captures the minimum functional scope for a Todo list with testable business requirements; covers CRUD for items, completion/reopening, filtering/sorting, localization, and acceptance criteria in EARS.
4. [todoApp User Stories and Personas](./04-todoApp-user-stories-and-personas.md)
   - Describes personas and primary/secondary scenarios to guide prioritization and testing; includes role-based scenarios and acceptance statements.
5. [todoApp User Flows and Process Diagrams](./05-todoApp-user-flows.md)
   - Provides visual business flows for core processes (authentication, item lifecycle, error and recovery) using Mermaid with LR orientation, plus narrative explanations.
6. [todoApp Business Rules Specification](./06-todoApp-business-rules.md)
   - Codifies validation rules, constraints, ownership rules, rate limits, retention, time zone handling, and rule precedence in measurable terms (EARS where applicable).
7. [todoApp Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md)
   - Defines user-facing error conditions, guidance, and recovery paths; covers conflicts, retries, monitoring expectations, and EARS-formatted error requirements.
8. [todoApp Non-Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md)
   - Sets measurable expectations for performance, security, privacy, availability, scalability, compliance, and operational monitoring; includes EARS-based acceptance criteria.
9. [todoApp Data Lifecycle and Privacy Requirements](./09-todoApp-data-lifecycle-and-privacy.md)
   - Describes conceptual information lifecycle, retention and purging policies, portability options, privacy-by-design principles, and right-to-erasure behaviors.
10. [todoApp Acceptance Criteria and Success Metrics](./10-todoApp-acceptance-criteria-and-success-metrics.md)
    - Defines go-live readiness, MVP acceptance criteria (EARS), post-launch monitoring plan, user satisfaction approach, KPIs, and risk mitigations.

### Recommended Reading Order and Rationale
- Foundation: Service overview → roles and authentication → functional requirements. Builds shared context, clarifies permissions, then defines scope.
- Behavior Details: User stories/personas → user flows → business rules. Translate scope into concrete scenarios, visual flows, and enforceable rules.
- Quality and Safety: Error handling → non-functional requirements. Define predictable failure behavior and measurable experience goals.
- Lifecycle and Acceptance: Data lifecycle and privacy → acceptance criteria and success metrics. Cover responsible data handling and evaluation of delivery.

### Role-Based Quick Paths
- Business stakeholders: Service overview → acceptance criteria and success metrics.
- Product managers: Service overview → functional requirements → user stories and personas → user flows.
- Development team: Roles and authentication → functional requirements → business rules → error handling → non-functional requirements → data lifecycle and privacy.
- QA and compliance: Business rules → error handling → non-functional requirements → data lifecycle and privacy → acceptance criteria and success metrics.

## Document Maintenance Policy
- Ownership: Product team curates business content; development team may propose clarifications via change requests. A designated documentation owner is accountable for approvals and publication.
- Update cadence: Update whenever scope, rules, or acceptance criteria change. Update this table of contents immediately when documents are added, renamed, or deprecated.
- Versioning and change log: Maintain a change log section or commit history within each document describing what changed and why in business terms.
- Link conventions: Use descriptive link text matching each document title in en-US; keep relative paths within this folder. Do not link to non-existent files.
- Consistency and traceability: Keep terminology, states, and rule names consistent across documents. Cross-reference related sections using descriptive links where helpful.
- Decommissioning: If a document is retired, remove its link here and record the successor or reason for removal in the project change log.

> *Developer Note: This document defines **business requirements only**. All technical implementations (architecture, APIs, database design, etc.) are at the discretion of the development team.*

files.content:
# todoApp Service Overview

## Executive Summary
A minimal, reliable, and privacy‑respecting personal task management service enabling individuals to quickly capture, organize, and complete tasks without distraction. The MVP emphasizes core value: todo creation, editing, completion/reopening, and deletion for authenticated users, with explicit ownership and predictable behavior across time zones.

Key outcomes for MVP:
- Accelerate time‑to‑first‑value: users create their first todo within one minute of registration (median).
- Establish daily habit loops centered on completion and review.
- Build trust through privacy‑first defaults and deterministic date/time handling.

EARS guiding objectives:
- THE todoApp SHALL enable a newly registered user to create a first todo within 60 seconds (median) from completing registration.
- THE todoApp SHALL keep each user’s todos private by default, with no sharing in MVP.
- WHEN a user records or modifies a due date, THE todoApp SHALL display and process that due date in the user’s preferred local time consistently.
- WHEN a user filters their todos, THE todoApp SHALL present results within user‑perceived expectations aligned with the non‑functional targets.

For deeper specifications, see the [Table of Contents and Navigation Guide](./00-toc.md), the [Functional Requirements for todoApp](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md), the [Non‑Functional Requirements for todoApp](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md), and the [Acceptance Criteria and Success Metrics for MVP](./10-todoApp-acceptance-criteria-and-success-metrics.md).

## Problem Definition and Market Gap
Many task tools try to satisfy both simple and complex workflows, burdening users who only need essentials. Observed pain points:
- Over‑featured products delaying time‑to‑first‑value due to configuration overhead.
- Privacy risk and unclear ownership in team‑oriented tools.
- Inconsistent due‑date handling across time zones, creating missed or premature deadlines.
- Reliability gaps in core actions (create, complete, find) that erode trust.
- Pricing complexity that discourages early adoption.

Competitor landscape (business characterization):
- Team‑centric platforms: optimized for collaboration; often complex for personal use; unclear privacy defaults.
- Power‑user task managers: rich features with steeper learning curves; slower activation for minimal needs.
- Simple list apps: fast but often lack rigorous ownership rules, retention clarity, and predictable date semantics.

Differentiation:
- Purposeful minimalism tied directly to value delivery.
- Privacy clarity and least‑privilege oversight.
- Deterministic time and date semantics across locales.

## Target Users
Primary audiences:
- Individual professionals, students, and early‑career knowledge workers who prefer predictability over breadth.
- Privacy‑conscious individuals seeking control and ownership of personal task data.

Secondary audience:
- Service administrators who provide user support and enforce policies under least‑privilege constraints.

Roles in service context:
- User: authenticated end user managing only their own todo items and account.
- Admin: administrative user performing limited oversight for support/policy enforcement with auditability.

## Core Value Proposition
- Minimalism with purpose: only capabilities that directly support capture and completion.
- Predictability: deterministic rules for ownership, visibility, and time semantics.
- Trust and privacy: personal data is private; no default sharing or exposure in MVP.
- Fast first value: immediate utility on first login.

Business value loop (conceptual):

```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Register"] --> B["Create First Todo(≤60s median)"]
  B --> C["Daily Review & Complete"]
  C --> D["Completion Satisfaction"]
  D --> E["Habit & Retention"]
  E --> F["Sustained Engagement"]
```

EARS commitments reinforcing value delivery:
- WHEN a newly verified account first signs in, THE todoApp SHALL make task capture immediately accessible without mandatory configuration.
- THE todoApp SHALL avoid features that do not materially improve capture, review, and completion during MVP.
- WHERE a user lacks a configured time zone, THE todoApp SHALL default to a reasonable locale‑aligned time zone (see non‑functional expectations) and communicate the default in context.

## Service Scope and Out‑of‑Scope

### In Scope (MVP)
- User accounts: registration, login, logout, email verification, password reset, session revocation (business perspective only).
- Todo item management: create, read, update, complete, reopen, delete personal items.
- Optional attributes: description and due date.
- Filtering and sorting: by completion status and due date; ordering by creation time or due date.
- Ownership and privacy: strict separation; users access only their data; admins act only for support under audit.
- Time zone semantics: consistent date/time handling per user preference.
- Data lifecycle basics: user‑initiated deletion; account deletion with retention policy adherence.

### Out of Scope (MVP)
- Collaboration: sharing, assignments, comments, team workspaces, mentions.
- Complex structures: subtasks, tags/labels, priorities, recurring tasks.
- Media: file/image attachments.
- Integrations: calendar sync, third‑party automations, external identity providers.
- Notifications/reminders: push/SMS/email reminders.
- Advanced analytics dashboards for end users.
- Public APIs or developer platform guarantees.
- Client platform specifics (no UI/UX or native app prescriptions).

Boundary EARS:
- THE todoApp SHALL exclude sharing and collaboration features in MVP.
- IF a feature introduces privacy ambiguity or increases time‑to‑first‑value beyond 60 seconds (median), THEN THE todoApp SHALL defer it beyond MVP.

## Business Model
Emphasizes a trust‑first entry with a minimal product, followed by value‑based monetization once habit and trust are validated.

Value creation and capture:
- Reliable, distraction‑free personal task management that improves completion rate and reduces anxiety.
- Free tier at launch to maximize adoption and learning; subscription options post‑MVP for power users and small teams while keeping core personal use free.

Cost structure (business level):
- Customer support and content for onboarding and guidance.
- Operations and compliance appropriate to geography and scale.
- Privacy and security program proportional to risk and data footprint.

Differentiation:
- Privacy clarity and least‑privilege operations.
- Deterministic time zone semantics and predictable behavior.
- Purposeful minimalism avoiding feature sprawl.

Guardrails (EARS):
- THE todoApp SHALL not introduce monetization that blocks basic personal task creation, completion, or deletion during MVP.
- WHERE monetization is later introduced, THE todoApp SHALL ensure continuity of access to existing data for users who downgrade.

## Why This Service Exists
Market need: a simple, dependable system without team constructs or heavy configuration.
Opportunity: competitors optimize for breadth and collaboration, underserving users seeking speed, clarity, and privacy.
Strategic fit: a minimal, high‑trust core creates a durable foundation for optional premium extensions without compromising simplicity.

EARS business objectives:
- THE todoApp SHALL minimize time‑to‑first‑value, targeting first‑todo creation ≤60 seconds (median) after registration.
- THE todoApp SHALL maintain privacy by default; no exposure of personal tasks to others in MVP.
- WHERE a free tier is offered, THE todoApp SHALL retain full personal task functionality in that tier during MVP.

## Revenue Strategy
Phased monetization to follow demonstrated engagement and retention.
- MVP to early traction: free tier for personal use to maximize adoption and learn from usage patterns.
- Post‑MVP (contingent on traction):
  - Individual Pro: advanced filters, export options, and optional productivity insights.
  - Teams (future): oversight and policy tools only if simplicity is preserved.
- Pricing principles: transparent, predictable, and free from hidden limits that undermine personal use.

EARS monetization ethics:
- THE todoApp SHALL avoid paywalls on core personal task operations during MVP.
- IF a user downgrades from paid to free, THEN THE todoApp SHALL preserve access to all existing personal tasks without data loss.

## Growth Plan
Acquisition: content marketing on productivity fundamentals; referrals; distribution via student and early‑career communities.
Activation: frictionless onboarding oriented to first task creation; contextual, minimal guidance.
Retention: habit loops centered on completion; simple in‑product prompts within MVP scope; weekly reflection content.
Expansion: optional premium features introduced only after healthy retention; core remains uncluttered.

EARS growth targets:
- THE todoApp SHALL achieve a median time‑to‑first‑task of ≤60 seconds for newly registered users during MVP.
- THE todoApp SHALL target 7‑day retention ≥25% within 90 days post‑launch.
- WHERE a referral mechanism is offered, THE todoApp SHALL allow invitation flows that do not introduce sharing features.

## Success Metrics and KPIs
Definitions (business level):
- Activation rate: % of new registrants creating a todo within 24 hours.
- Time‑to‑first‑task (median): time from registration to first todo creation.
- Weekly engaged users: users who created, updated, or completed at least one todo in a 7‑day window.
- Completion ratio: completed todos / created todos within a period.
- Churn rate: % of active users who become inactive over 30 days.
- Support ticket volume per 1,000 MAU: proxy for usability and reliability.

Targets (EARS):
- THE todoApp SHALL achieve activation rate ≥70% within 90 days post‑launch.
- THE todoApp SHALL maintain median time‑to‑first‑task ≤60 seconds during MVP.
- THE todoApp SHALL achieve weekly completion ratio ≥50% for active users within 90 days post‑launch.
- WHERE support is provided, THE todoApp SHALL keep support ticket volume ≤20 per 1,000 MAU related to core operations.

Illustrative KPI table:

| KPI | Definition | MVP Target |
|-----|------------|------------|
| Activation rate | % new users with ≥1 todo in 24h | ≥ 70% |
| Time‑to‑first‑task | Median time to first todo | ≤ 60 s |
| Weekly completion ratio | Completed / created (active users) | ≥ 50% |
| 7‑day retention | Users returning within 7 days | ≥ 25% |
| Support volume | Tickets per 1,000 MAU | ≤ 20 |

## Assumptions and Dependencies
Assumptions:
- Email channel availability for verification and password resets.
- Baseline compliance (privacy/legal) for operating regions; documented consent for data processing.
- Stable time zone rules and consistent business semantics for due dates.
- English‑language product framing for MVP; broader localization later.
- Reasonable baseline of user devices and connectivity.
- Administrative oversight limited to support/policy enforcement with least‑privilege principles.

Dependencies:
- Content and onboarding materials to reduce activation friction.
- Support capacity for early launch weeks to handle inquiries.
- Monitoring and analytics to measure activation, retention, and completion.

Constraints (EARS):
- IF email verification is not completed within a defined grace period, THEN THE todoApp SHALL limit access to functions requiring verified identity until verification is complete.
- WHILE account deletion is in progress, THE todoApp SHALL prevent new content creation to avoid data inconsistency.
- WHERE privacy policy prohibits data sharing, THE todoApp SHALL avoid features that expose personal content to others during MVP.

## Linkage to Detailed Requirements
Business behavior and acceptance details are elaborated in the [Functional Requirements for todoApp](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md). User‑perceived reliability, performance, security, and privacy expectations are set in the [Non‑Functional Requirements for todoApp](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md). Release readiness and measurable acceptance criteria are defined in the [Acceptance Criteria and Success Metrics for MVP](./10-todoApp-acceptance-criteria-and-success-metrics.md).

## Glossary of Terms
- Activation: point at which a newly registered user creates the first todo.
- Admin: role authorized to perform limited oversight for support and policy enforcement with auditability.
- Completion ratio: completed todos divided by created todos over the same period.
- Due date: optional date attached to a todo indicating a target completion day in the user’s local time.
- Habit loop: recurring cycle of capture, review, and completion that fosters retention.
- MVP: minimal set of features delivering core value and validating the product hypothesis.
- Ownership: principle that a user’s todos belong exclusively to that user and are not visible to others in MVP.
- Retention: rate at which users return and interact with the service over time.
- Time‑to‑first‑task: elapsed time between account registration and first todo creation.
- User: authenticated end user who manages only their own todo items and account.

Business scope statement: This document provides business requirements and outcomes only. All technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, infrastructure) are at the discretion of the development team; the content defines WHAT the system should do, not HOW to build it.

files.content:
# todoApp User Roles and Authentication Requirements

Business requirements only. Technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, storage, libraries) belong to the development team. Content specifies WHAT the service must do in business terms.

## Purpose and Scope
- Define authentication behaviors, role hierarchy, and permissions so access rules are unambiguous in business terms.
- Establish session and token management principles, including lifetimes, rotation, revocation, re‑authentication for sensitive actions, and session listing.
- Specify account lifecycle stages and expected business outcomes (creation, verification, suspension, deletion and restoration windows).
- Provide EARS‑formatted, testable requirements for core auth flows and access control.
- Exclude technical implementation details such as API endpoints, database schemas, or infrastructure choices.

## Authentication Requirements (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL support end‑user authentication with email and password.
- THE todoApp SHALL require email verification to unlock sensitive account actions and data export.
- WHEN a person authenticates successfully, THE todoApp SHALL establish a session represented by issued tokens according to token management rules.
- WHEN a subject without a valid session attempts to access protected resources, THE todoApp SHALL deny access and guide the subject to sign in or verify email as applicable.
- WHEN administrative assistance is necessary, THE todoApp SHALL allow authorized administrators to perform limited support actions under least‑privilege and full audit.

### Visual Overview of Core Authentication Flows
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Registration and Verification"
    A1["User Submits Registration(Email, Password)"] --> A2["Validate Input(Format, Policy)"]
    A2 --> A3{"Valid?"}
    A3 -->|"Yes"| A4["Create Account(Pending Verification)"]
    A3 -->|"No"| A5["Inform Validation Errors"]
    A4 --> A6["Send Verification Email(Link, 24h Expiry)"]
    A6 --> A7["User Clicks Verification Link"]
    A7 --> A8{"Token Valid and Not Expired?"}
    A8 -->|"Yes"| A9["Mark Email Verified"]
    A8 -->|"No"| A10["Inform Link Invalid or Expired"]
  end

  subgraph "Login and Session Management"
    B1["User Submits Login(Email, Password)"] --> B2["Validate Credentials"]
    B2 --> B3{"Successful?"}
    B3 -->|"Yes"| B4["Issue Access Token(20m)"]
    B3 -->|"Yes"| B5["Issue Refresh Token(30d, Rotating)"]
    B3 -->|"No"| B6["Increment Failure Counter and Inform"]
    B4 --> B7["Authorized Access to Own Resources"]
    B5 -.-> B8["Refresh Flow: Rotate Refresh Token"]
    B8 -.-> B4
  end
```

## Core Authentication Functions (register, login, logout, verify email, reset password, change password, revoke sessions)
All applicable requirements use EARS.

### Registration
- WHEN a person submits registration details (email, password), THE todoApp SHALL validate format and enforce password policy.
- IF registration input violates policy, THEN THE todoApp SHALL present the specific validation reason without exposing sensitive checks.
- WHEN registration is valid, THE todoApp SHALL create the account in unverified status.
- WHEN an account is created, THE todoApp SHALL send a verification message containing a time‑limited link.
- THE todoApp SHALL set verification link validity to 24 hours from issuance.
- WHERE a verification link expires, THE todoApp SHALL allow resend requests up to 3 times within 24 hours.

### Login
- WHEN a person submits email and password, THE todoApp SHALL validate credentials and provide success or failure within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- IF credentials are valid and the account is eligible, THEN THE todoApp SHALL issue an access token (valid 20 minutes) and a refresh token (valid 30 days, rotating on use).
- IF credentials are invalid, THEN THE todoApp SHALL present a generic failure message that does not disclose which field failed and SHALL encourage secure recovery.
- WHILE an account is locked under security policy, THE todoApp SHALL deny login and present the unlock time or procedure.

### Logout
- WHEN a signed‑in user requests logout, THE todoApp SHALL immediately invalidate the active session for that device.
- WHERE a user chooses “log out from all devices”, THE todoApp SHALL immediately revoke all active sessions and refresh tokens for that user.

### Email Verification
- WHEN a person clicks a verification link, THE todoApp SHALL validate token integrity and expiry.
- IF the link is valid and not expired, THEN THE todoApp SHALL mark the account email as verified.
- IF the link is invalid or expired, THEN THE todoApp SHALL inform verification failure and provide a resend path.

### Reset Password
- WHEN a person requests password reset by providing an email, THE todoApp SHALL return a standard confirmation that does not disclose whether the email is registered.
- WHEN reset instructions are dispatched, THE todoApp SHALL attempt delivery within 60 seconds under normal conditions.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit password reset link validity to 1 hour from issuance.
- IF a reset token is valid and unexpired, THEN THE todoApp SHALL enforce the current password policy on the new password and, on success, SHALL revoke all existing sessions with an option to preserve the current device session at the user’s choice.

### Change Password (Authenticated)
- WHEN a signed‑in user requests a password change, THE todoApp SHALL validate the current password and the new password against policy.
- IF validation succeeds, THEN THE todoApp SHALL update the password and revoke existing device sessions with an option to preserve the current device session at the user’s choice.

### Revoke Sessions
- WHEN a user performs “revoke all sessions”, THE todoApp SHALL immediately invalidate all active access and refresh tokens for that user.
- WHEN an administrator revokes a specific user’s sessions for safety or policy reasons, THE todoApp SHALL immediately invalidate all of that user’s sessions and notify the user through an approved communication channel.

## User Role Structure
- Roles in scope: user, admin.
- Role hierarchy: admin has elevated privileges relative to user but remains bound by accountability, privacy, and least‑privilege rules.
- Unauthenticated: a state (guest) with no access to protected resources; not a role.

## Role Definitions and Capabilities

### user
- Purpose: authenticated end user managing only their own todo items and account.
- Can: create, read, update, complete, and delete personal items; manage own profile and security; list and revoke own sessions; export own data; delete own account subject to lifecycle policy; request password reset; change password; verify email.
- Cannot: access or modify other users’ data or sessions; view audit logs; view aggregated analytics; change service‑wide settings; assign roles.
- Business‑level JWT claims: userId; role="user"; permissions=["todo:own:read", "todo:own:write", "account:own:manage", "session:own:manage", "export:own"].

### admin
- Purpose: administrative user performing oversight for support and policy enforcement.
- Can: suspend or reactivate user accounts with recorded reason; revoke user sessions; assist with account recovery via approved flows; access aggregated analytics; access audit trails; configure service‑wide settings within policy; trigger user data export upon verified lawful request.
- Cannot: view or retrieve user passwords; access user content beyond the minimum necessary for support/policy enforcement without explicit justification; impersonate users without an approved process.
- Business‑level JWT claims: userId; role="admin"; permissions=["user:any:manage", "session:any:manage", "analytics:aggregate:view", "audit:trail:view", "settings:service:manage"].

## Permission Matrix (actions by role)
Note: “Unauthenticated” is a state, not a role.

| Action | Unauthenticated | user | admin |
|-------|------------------|------|-------|
| Register account | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ |
| Login | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ |
| Verify email | ✅ (via link) | ✅ | ✅ (resend support) |
| View own todos | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ (for support with justification) |
| Create/update/delete own todos | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ (for support with justification) |
| View another user’s todos | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ (unless authorized support action) |
| View own profile/account | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Update own profile/account | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ (for support with authorization) |
| Change own password | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Request password reset | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ (on behalf of user) |
| List own sessions | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Revoke own sessions | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Revoke another user’s sessions | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Suspend/reactivate user account | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Delete own account | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ (upon lawful request) |
| Access aggregated analytics | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Access audit logs | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Configure service‑wide settings | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |

## Session and Token Management (business rules)
- THE todoApp SHALL use JWT for access and refresh tokens for session representation.
- THE todoApp SHALL issue access tokens with a validity of 20 minutes.
- THE todoApp SHALL issue refresh tokens with a validity of 30 days and rotate them on each successful refresh, immediately invalidating the prior refresh token.
- THE todoApp SHALL bind each session to a logical device/session identifier to enable session listing and selective revocation.
- WHERE a user changes password, THE todoApp SHALL revoke all existing sessions and refresh tokens, with an option to preserve the current device session only when explicitly chosen by the user.
- WHERE an administrator enforces a password reset or security hold, THE todoApp SHALL revoke all sessions for that user without exception.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit concurrent active sessions per user to 10; attempts to establish an 11th SHALL require the user to revoke at least one existing session or accept automatic revocation of the oldest idle session.
- THE todoApp SHALL provide session metadata for user viewing: creation time, last activity time, device label (if provided by the user), and approximate location derived from coarse signals where permitted by policy.
- THE todoApp SHALL require recent re‑authentication (within the last 15 minutes) before sensitive actions such as password change, email change, account deletion, or export of personal data.
- THE todoApp SHALL treat token storage location as a developer decision, requiring that storage be resistant to common attacks appropriate to the platform.
- THE todoApp SHALL include in each JWT at minimum: userId, role, and a permissions array sufficient for authorization decisions.

## Access Control Rules and Examples (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL enforce least privilege so users access only resources they own unless an administrative support action is justified and recorded.
- WHEN an unauthenticated subject requests a protected resource, THE todoApp SHALL deny access and guide the subject to authenticate or verify email.
- WHEN a user attempts to read, modify, or delete another user’s resources, THE todoApp SHALL deny access without revealing resource existence.
- WHEN an administrator suspends or reactivates an account, THE todoApp SHALL record the reason and notify the affected user.
- WHEN an administrator must view user data for support, THE todoApp SHALL permit the minimum necessary access within an approved process and SHALL record all actions in audit logs.
- IF an account email is unverified, THEN THE todoApp SHALL restrict sensitive features (for example, export or account deletion) and guide the user to complete verification first.
- WHERE abnormal activity is detected by policy (for example, repeated failed logins), THE todoApp SHALL apply additional checks or temporary limits such as cooldowns or step‑up verification.

## Account Lifecycle (creation, verification, suspension, deletion)

### Creation
- WHEN creating an account, THE todoApp SHALL use email as the unique contact identifier and enforce the current password policy.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit registration attempt frequency to prevent automated abuse using policy‑based thresholds (for example, per IP or per domain).

### Verification
- THE todoApp SHALL allow verification link resend subject to 3 requests within any 24‑hour window.
- IF verification is not completed within 7 days, THEN THE todoApp SHALL require verification at the next login before granting access to sensitive features.
- WHERE an account remains unverified for 14 days, THE todoApp SHALL purge the unverified account and associated artifacts during the next scheduled purge cycle.

### Suspension
- WHEN a user requests voluntary deactivation, THE todoApp SHALL restrict sign‑in and convert the account to a reversible inactive state according to retention policy.
- WHEN an administrator suspends an account for policy violations, THE todoApp SHALL terminate all active sessions immediately and record suspension reason, start time, and review schedule.
- WHILE an account is suspended, THE todoApp SHALL block write operations and sensitive actions and MAY allow read access to security pages sufficient to complete recovery.

### Deletion
- WHEN a verified user confirms account deletion, THE todoApp SHALL initiate a 14‑day grace period during which the user may cancel deletion.
- WHILE the grace period is active, THE todoApp SHALL present a deletion‑cancellation option at sign‑in and restrict normal write operations.
- IF legal retention obligations apply to specific records, THEN THE todoApp SHALL defer deletion of those records while deleting all other user data and SHALL inform the user within policy limits.

## Security and Privacy Considerations

### Password Policy
- THE todoApp SHALL require a minimum password length of 8 characters and SHALL accept long passphrases without requiring special characters.
- THE todoApp SHALL prevent use of commonly compromised passwords using a banned list.
- THE todoApp SHALL prevent reuse of the previous 5 passwords.

### Rate Limiting and Lockouts
- THE todoApp SHALL impose a cooldown after 10 failed login attempts within 10 minutes for an account or from a single source; cooldown duration SHALL be at least 5 minutes with clear guidance.
- THE todoApp SHALL throttle password reset requests to a maximum of 5 per 24 hours per account.

### Privacy by Design
- THE todoApp SHALL avoid revealing whether an email is registered in responses to registration and password reset requests.
- THE todoApp SHALL record audit events without storing sensitive secrets (for example, no plaintext passwords, no full tokens in logs).
- THE todoApp SHALL store audit timestamps in UTC while displaying times to users according to their locale settings where applicable.

### Notifications and Messaging
- THE todoApp SHALL send verification and password reset emails within 60 seconds under normal operating conditions.
- THE todoApp SHALL ensure messages avoid sensitive data and provide clear next steps for recovery.

### Administrative Safeguards
- THE todoApp SHALL require administrators to provide a reason when performing user‑impacting actions (suspension, session revocation, role modification).
- THE todoApp SHALL restrict access to aggregated analytics to administrators only and ensure data is de‑identified at the individual level.

## Audit and Activity Logging (business expectations)
- THE todoApp SHALL record at minimum the following categories: registration, email verification initiation/completion, login success/failure, logout, password reset request/completion, password change, session creation/refresh/revocation, account suspension/reactivation, account deletion request/completion, admin configuration changes, and elevated user‑data access by administrators.
- WHEN an audit event is recorded, THE todoApp SHALL include event type, actor (user or admin), timestamp (UTC), target (if applicable), outcome (success/failure), and reason (if applicable).
- WHERE an administrator accesses user data, THE todoApp SHALL classify the event as high‑risk and route it to a review queue.
- THE todoApp SHALL provide each user with access to their own audit history for security‑relevant actions (for example, logins, password changes, session revocations).

## Related Documents
- Service vision and business model: [todoApp Service Overview](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md)
- End‑to‑end feature behaviors: [todoApp Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md)
- Failure behaviors and recovery: [todoApp Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md)
- Performance, availability, and privacy expectations: [todoApp Non‑Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md)

---

## Appendix: Additional EARS Examples for Edge Cases
- IF a password reset token was already used, THEN THE todoApp SHALL treat the token as invalid and guide the user to request a new one.
- IF abnormal refresh activity is observed from the same device/session, THEN THE todoApp SHALL terminate the session and require re‑authentication.
- WHERE a user saves a custom label for a device, THE todoApp SHALL display the label in the session list.
- WHEN an account deletion grace period ends, THE todoApp SHALL complete permanent deletion and notify the user through the configured channel.
- WHILE an account is suspended, THE todoApp SHALL block authentication to protected features and present suspension reason and review schedule at the next sign‑in attempt.

files.reason: Capture the minimum functional scope for a Todo list and write testable business requirements for developers.
outline: Todo Item Management (Create, Read, Update, Delete)
keyQuestions: What minimum features must the Todo service support?
What fields are required for a todo item and what validations apply?
How should filtering and sorting work from a business perspective?
What are the acceptance criteria for the MVP scope?
constraints: Use EARS format wherever applicable
Do not define any API endpoints or database schemas
Keep scope minimal while ensuring a complete, usable product
files.content:
# todoApp Functional Requirements (MVP)

## Overview of Minimal Feature Set

- Personal Todo lists scoped to authenticated users with strict item ownership and privacy by default.
- Core item operations: create, read (list and detail), update, delete to trash, restore, and purge per retention policy.
- State transitions for completion and reopening with timestamp semantics.
- Optional attributes: description and due date (date-only semantics by default).
- Business-level filtering and sorting for lists with stable defaults and user-selected variations.
- Time zone and localization rules: user’s profile time zone governs evaluation and display; DST-safe semantics.
- Role-aware access control in business terms aligned with the roles and authentication specification.
- Optional data export for portability (import out-of-scope for MVP).
- Explicit constraints and limits on fields, inventory, and operation frequency.

Related references:
- Business context and KPIs: [todoApp Service Overview](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md)
- Roles, authentication, and permissions: [todoApp User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md)
- Cross-cutting rules and state logic: [todoApp Business Rules and Constraints](./06-todoApp-business-rules.md)
- Error behavior and recovery: [todoApp Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md)
- Performance, security, and availability targets: [todoApp Non-Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md)

## Principles and Scope Notes

- Minimal scope focuses on personal task management with item-level operations. No collaboration, tags, subtasks, reminders, or external integrations in MVP.
- Business-only specification: requirements expressed in natural language using EARS where applicable; no API endpoints, data schemas, or technology choices.
- Roles in scope: "user" (owns personal items) and "admin" (limited oversight for support/policy with audit and least privilege).

## User Roles and Access Context (Business Perspective)

- "user": Authenticated end user who can manage only owned items and personal account.
- "admin": Administrative actor who may access a user’s items only for legitimate support or policy enforcement with strict accountability.

EARS requirements:
- THE todoApp SHALL restrict access to todo items by ownership so that a "user" can create, read, update, complete/reopen, trash/restore, and purge only their own items.
- WHERE administrative oversight is justified for support or policy enforcement, THE todoApp SHALL allow "admin" to access the minimum necessary user items for the task under audit.

## Todo Item Management (Create, Read, Update, Delete/Trash/Restore/Purge)

### Data Elements (Business-Level)
- Title (required): Short text identifying the item.
- Description (optional): Extended text elaborating the task.
- Due Date (optional): Target completion date interpreted in the user’s time zone; default date-only semantics (end-of-day).
- Status (system-managed): "open" or "completed".
- Created Time / Updated Time (system-managed): Timestamps captured on create and on each successful edit.
- Completion Time (system-managed): Timestamp captured when status becomes "completed" and cleared on reopen.
- Owner (system-managed): The user who created the item.
- Deletion State (system-managed): "active" (not trashed), "trashed" (soft-deleted), or "purged" (irreversible).

### Validation Rules (Business-Level)
- Title length: 1 to 120 Unicode characters after trimming leading/trailing whitespace; control characters not allowed.
- Description length: 0 to 2,000 Unicode characters after trimming; control characters not allowed.
- Due Date range: Not earlier than 1 January 1970 in the user’s time zone; not more than 10 years in the future.

EARS requirements (creation and update):
- WHEN a "user" submits a new todo with a valid title, THE todoApp SHALL create the item with status "open" and set Created Time and Updated Time.
- IF a title is missing or its trimmed length is 0, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject creation and instruct to provide a valid title of 1–120 characters without control characters.
- IF a title exceeds 120 characters, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject creation and instruct to shorten the title to 120 characters or fewer.
- IF a description exceeds 2,000 characters, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject creation or update and instruct to reduce the description to 2,000 characters or fewer.
- IF a due date is provided earlier than 1 January 1970 (user-local) or more than 10 years in the future, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the due date and prompt selection of a valid date.
- THE todoApp SHALL update Updated Time on any successful edit of title, description, due date, or status.
- THE todoApp SHALL allow a "user" to read (list and detail) only items owned by that user.
- WHERE an "admin" views a user’s items for support, THE todoApp SHALL indicate the acting role and subject user context.

### Concurrency and Conflict Handling

EARS requirements:
- IF a concurrent modification is detected during update, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent silent overwrite and require the user to refresh or reconcile prior to saving.
- WHEN reconciliation is required after a conflict, THE todoApp SHALL present guidance that enables retry with the latest version without losing the user’s attempted edits.

### Deletion, Restoration, and Purging

Definitions:
- Trash (soft-delete): Move an item from active/completed to trashed; hidden from normal listings; restorable within retention window.
- Restore: Return an item from trashed to active state; retain prior fields other than deletion metadata.
- Purge (hard delete): Irreversibly remove a trashed item after retention or upon explicit user purge.

EARS requirements:
- WHEN a "user" deletes an item they own, THE todoApp SHALL move the item to "trashed" and exclude it from normal lists while starting a 30-day retention countdown.
- WHILE an item is "trashed" within retention, THE todoApp SHALL allow the owner to restore it to the "open" status with all fields preserved and clear deletion metadata.
- WHEN a "trashed" item reaches the retention deadline, THE todoApp SHALL purge it automatically in the next scheduled purge cycle.
- WHEN a "user" explicitly purges a "trashed" item, THE todoApp SHALL remove it irreversibly and exclude it from all user-accessible views.
- IF a "user" attempts to view or modify another user’s trashed items, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny access and avoid revealing existence.

### Pagination and List Size (Business Expectations)

EARS requirements:
- THE todoApp SHALL present lists in pages of up to 20 items by default, ordered by the default sort policy.
- WHERE a user chooses a different page size, THE todoApp SHALL support 10, 20, 50, or 100 items per page and remember the preference per user.

## Completion and Reopening of Items

Definitions:
- Complete: Transition status from "open" to "completed" and record Completion Time.
- Reopen: Transition status from "completed" to "open" and clear Completion Time.

EARS requirements:
- WHEN a "user" marks an "open" item as completed, THE todoApp SHALL set status to "completed" and record Completion Time.
- IF an item is already "completed" and a user attempts to complete it again, THEN THE todoApp SHALL keep status unchanged and inform that the item is already completed.
- WHEN a "user" reopens a "completed" item, THE todoApp SHALL set status to "open" and clear Completion Time.
- IF a "user" completes an item with a due date in the past, THEN THE todoApp SHALL allow completion and retain the past due date for historical accuracy.
- THE todoApp SHALL allow editing of title, description, and due date regardless of status unless restricted by policy.

## Optional Attributes (description, due date)

EARS requirements:
- WHERE a description is provided, THE todoApp SHALL store and present it with the item.
- WHERE a due date is provided as a date-only value, THE todoApp SHALL interpret it as due by end-of-day in the user’s time zone.
- IF a due date is removed by the user, THEN THE todoApp SHALL persist the item without a due date and update Updated Time.
- WHERE no due date is provided, THE todoApp SHALL treat the item as having no scheduling constraint.

## Filtering and Sorting (business expectations)

Supported filters (combinable):
- Status: open, completed, trashed (optional view), or all non-trashed.
- Due date window: today, tomorrow, this week (Mon–Sun in user’s locale), next week, overdue (due date earlier than today), or no due date.
- Text match: case-insensitive contains over title and description.
- Created/Updated date ranges: calendar-based, using the user’s time zone.

Supported sorting:
- Default: due date ascending, items without due date ordered last; ties by created time descending.
- Alternatives: due date descending; created time descending; updated time descending; title ascending.

EARS requirements:
- THE todoApp SHALL allow a "user" to filter by status, due date window, text match, and date ranges simultaneously.
- THE todoApp SHALL apply the default sorting when no explicit sort is chosen: due date ascending with items without due date last and ties by created time descending.
- WHERE a user selects a different sort, THE todoApp SHALL apply the selected order consistently across pages.
- IF filters yield zero results, THEN THE todoApp SHALL present an empty result with guidance to adjust filters.
- WHILE filters are active, THE todoApp SHALL maintain the active filter set when a user navigates between pages of results.

## Time Zone and Localization Behaviors

Business baseline for MVP:
- Default service time zone: Asia/Seoul (KST, UTC+9) when a profile time zone is not set.
- User time zone preference: Every date evaluation and display uses the user’s profile time zone if available.
- Calendar day semantics: Due date represents obligation by the end of the calendar day in the user’s time zone.

EARS requirements:
- THE todoApp SHALL display Created Time, Updated Time, and Completion Time in the user’s profile time zone where available, otherwise in Asia/Seoul (KST, UTC+9).
- WHEN determining whether an item is overdue, THE todoApp SHALL compare the due date’s end-of-day boundary to the current date in the user’s time zone.
- WHERE a user changes the profile time zone, THE todoApp SHALL re-interpret and display existing due dates and timestamps in the new time zone without altering original calendar date values.
- IF a due date falls on a day affected by DST in the chosen time zone, THEN THE todoApp SHALL maintain end-of-day semantics consistently and adjust non-existent local times to the next valid time.

## Data Ownership and Privacy Rules

EARS requirements:
- THE todoApp SHALL associate each item with exactly one owner (the creator) and treat it as private by default.
- IF a "user" attempts to view or modify another user’s items (including trashed items), THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny access and avoid revealing existence.
- WHERE an "admin" performs support actions on a user’s items, THE todoApp SHALL record the acting role context and restrict visibility to the minimum necessary data.

## Import/Export and Data Portability (optional)

Scope: Export in scope; import out of scope for MVP.

EARS requirements:
- WHERE a "user" requests an export, THE todoApp SHALL provide a file containing all owned items and attributes (title, description, due date if present, status, Created/Updated/Completion Times, deletion state where applicable) in a commonly portable format.
- IF an export is requested while no items exist, THEN THE todoApp SHALL produce a valid export file containing zero items and an indication that the list is empty.
- WHERE an export is processed asynchronously, THE todoApp SHALL notify the user upon completion using available communication channels defined in policy.

## Business Constraints and Limits

EARS requirements:
- THE todoApp SHALL limit title length to 120 characters and description length to 2,000 characters.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit due dates to within 10 years into the future and not earlier than 1 January 1970 in the user’s time zone.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit items per page to 10, 20, 50, or 100 with a default of 20.
- THE todoApp SHALL allow up to 5,000 active (non-trashed) items per user; attempts to exceed this SHALL be denied with guidance to archive, delete, or purge.
- THE todoApp SHALL allow up to 5,000 trashed items retained per user; where this cap is exceeded, older trashed items SHALL be purged first.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit total items per user (all states except purged) to 10,000.
- WHERE operational stability requires, THE todoApp SHALL throttle per-user operation frequency as follows: create up to 30 items/minute; update up to 60 items/minute; complete/reopen up to 120 state changes/minute; trash/restore up to 60 operations/minute; purge up to 30 operations/minute.

## Process Flows (Business-Level)

The following Mermaid diagrams visualize end-to-end business flows in LR orientation; they express business behavior, not technical design.

### Create Todo Item
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Initiates Create"] --> B["Enter Title/Optional Fields"]
  B --> C["Validate Business Rules"]
  C --> D{"Valid?"}
  D -->|"Yes"| E["Create Item(Status=open)"]
  E --> F["Set Created/Updated Times"]
  F --> G["Show Item in List"]
  D -->|"No"| H["Show Validation Guidance"]
```

### Complete and Reopen Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Selects Item"] --> B{"Current Status?"}
  B -->|"open"| C["Mark Completed"]
  C --> D["Record Completion Time"]
  D --> E["Reflect Status=completed"]
  B -->|"completed"| F["Reopen Item"]
  F --> G["Clear Completion Time"]
  G --> H["Reflect Status=open"]
```

### Delete, Restore, and Purge Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Selects Item"] --> B{"Delete?"}
  B -->|"Yes"| C["Move To Trashed"]
  C --> D["Hide From Normal Lists"]
  C --> E{"Restore Within Retention?"}
  E -->|"Yes"| F["Restore To Open"]
  F --> G["Clear Deletion Metadata"]
  E -->|"No"| H["Eligible For Automatic Purge"]
  H --> I["Purge Irreversibly"]
```

### Filtering and Sorting Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Opens List"] --> B["Apply Default Sort"]
  B --> C["User Sets Filters"]
  C --> D["Combine Filters"]
  D --> E["Fetch Page(Size per Preference)"]
  E --> F{"Any Results?"}
  F -->|"Yes"| G["Display Items"]
  F -->|"No"| H["Display Empty State Guidance"]
```

## Acceptance Criteria (EARS format)

Creation
- WHEN a "user" submits a new item with a valid title (1–120 chars), THE todoApp SHALL create the item with status "open" and display it in the list according to current sorting.
- IF the title is invalid (missing, zero-length after trim, or >120 chars), THEN THE todoApp SHALL block creation and present guidance to correct the title without losing entered data.
- WHERE a description up to 2,000 chars is provided, THE todoApp SHALL save it verbatim subject to control character restrictions.
- IF a due date is earlier than 1970-01-01 (user-local) or more than 10 years in the future, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the due date with clear guidance.

Reading
- THE todoApp SHALL present items in pages using the user’s preferred page size (default 20), sorted per the active sort rule.
- WHEN a "user" filters by status="open" and due date window="today", THE todoApp SHALL return only the user’s open items due today in the user’s time zone.
- IF a filter combination results in no matches, THEN THE todoApp SHALL display an empty state with guidance to adjust filters.

Updating and Conflicts
- WHEN a "user" edits fields, THE todoApp SHALL validate against creation rules and update Updated Time upon success.
- IF validation fails on update, THEN THE todoApp SHALL preserve existing data and present guidance to correct inputs.
- IF a concurrent modification is detected, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent silent overwrite and require refresh or reconciliation before saving.

Deletion, Restoration, and Purge
- WHEN a "user" deletes an owned item, THE todoApp SHALL move it to "trashed" and hide it from normal lists while starting the retention window.
- WHILE an item is in "trashed" state and within retention, THE todoApp SHALL allow restoration to the "open" status with prior content intact.
- WHEN the retention period elapses, THE todoApp SHALL purge the item in the next scheduled purge and remove it irreversibly.
- WHEN a "user" explicitly purges a "trashed" item, THE todoApp SHALL remove it irreversibly and it SHALL not appear in any listing or filter thereafter.

Completion/Reopen
- WHEN a "user" completes an open item, THE todoApp SHALL set status to "completed" and record Completion Time; the item SHALL still appear according to filters and sorting.
- WHEN a "user" reopens a completed item, THE todoApp SHALL set status to "open" and clear Completion Time; the item SHALL re-enter lists according to filters and sorting.

Filtering and Sorting
- THE todoApp SHALL support filters: status (open/completed/trashed or non-trashed), due date windows (today/tomorrow/this week/next week/overdue/no due date), text match, and created/updated date ranges.
- THE todoApp SHALL support sorts: due date ascending (default, none last; tie by created time desc), due date descending, created time desc, updated time desc, title asc.

Time Zone
- THE todoApp SHALL treat date-only due dates as end-of-day obligations in the user’s time zone and compute overdue accordingly.
- WHERE no profile time zone is set, THE todoApp SHALL default to Asia/Seoul (KST, UTC+9) for time calculations and displays.
- IF a due date falls within a DST gap, THEN THE todoApp SHALL adjust to the next valid local time and maintain end-of-day semantics for date-only values.

Ownership & Privacy
- THE todoApp SHALL ensure a user can access only their own items; admin may access items for support per policy with audit.
- IF cross-user access is attempted by a non-admin, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny and present a privacy message.

Export
- WHERE a user requests export, THE todoApp SHALL produce a portable file containing all owned items and attributes, including timestamps, status, and deletion state, consistent with current time zone display rules.
- IF no items exist, THEN THE todoApp SHALL produce a valid export file with zero items and a clear indication of emptiness.

Limits and Rate Controls
- THE todoApp SHALL enforce per-user maxima of 5,000 active items, 5,000 trashed items (purging oldest first when exceeded), and 10,000 total items excluding purged.
- THE todoApp SHALL enforce per-minute operation limits for create (30), update (60), complete/reopen (120), trash/restore (60), and purge (30), presenting user-friendly guidance when limits are reached.

## Traceability and Related Documents

- Business vision and KPIs: [todoApp Service Overview](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md)
- Roles, permissions, and authentication: [todoApp User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md)
- Cross-cutting validations, state logic, and retention: [todoApp Business Rules and Constraints](./06-todoApp-business-rules.md)
- User-facing failures and recovery: [todoApp Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md)
- Performance and availability targets: [todoApp Non-Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md)

files.reason: Describe who uses the system and the primary/secondary scenarios to guide requirement prioritization and testing.
outline: Acceptance Tests in Natural Language (EARS where applicable)
keyQuestions: Who are the typical users of this service?
What scenarios are most critical to support?
What edge cases must be considered for MVP?
constraints: Avoid UI/UX design details and screen layouts
Use natural language and business logic only
Write acceptance tests in EARS where possible
files.content:
# todoApp User Stories and Personas

## Personas

### Persona 1: Focused Professional (User)
- Profile: Employed knowledge worker balancing multiple projects and deadlines.
- Goals: Capture tasks quickly, prioritize by urgency, complete tasks on schedule, review what’s done.
- Motivations: Reduce mental load, maintain reliability, demonstrate progress.
- Pain Points: Task sprawl across tools, forgetting deadlines, difficulty filtering by status.
- Environment: Desktop during work hours; mobile on the go. Intermittent connectivity possible.
- Success Measures: Can capture a task in under 10 seconds; can find any task within 5 seconds via filtering or search-like mechanisms; misses no critical due date over a week.

### Persona 2: Organized Student (User)
- Profile: University student juggling classes, assignments, and part-time work.
- Goals: Track assignments by due dates, mark completed work, reopen items when requirements change.
- Motivations: Stay ahead of deadlines, visualize workload by due date, avoid penalties.
- Pain Points: Overdue tracking confusion, accidental deletions, unclear item states.
- Environment: Mobile-first; occasional desktop sessions in labs or dorm.
- Success Measures: Keeps assignment list current daily; can see upcoming items due this week within 2 seconds; can undo a completion or correct a mistake without data loss.

### Persona 3: Casual Planner (User)
- Profile: Non-technical individual using the app occasionally for personal reminders.
- Goals: Add simple reminders, check off completed items, clear clutter periodically.
- Motivations: Minimal friction, clarity of state (open vs completed), confidence items aren’t lost.
- Pain Points: Complexity overload, needlessly required fields, confusing error messages.
- Environment: Mobile with variable connectivity.
- Success Measures: Zero confusion about item state; never blocked by optional fields; can delete or archive clutter quickly.

### Persona 4: Support Administrator (Admin)
- Profile: Service operator ensuring policy compliance and user support.
- Goals: Assist users with account issues, enforce content and safety policies, monitor basic health indicators at a business level.
- Motivations: Maintain trust and safety, minimize support burden, resolve issues quickly.
- Pain Points: Ambiguity around user permissions, incomplete audit trails, difficulty revoking sessions when necessary.
- Environment: Desktop in secure environment.
- Success Measures: Can locate a user account within seconds; can revoke sessions and suspend/restore accounts swiftly with clear outcomes; minimal escalations.

## User Stories per Persona

### Focused Professional
- As a focused professional, I want to capture a new task with only a title so that I can record intent without friction.
- As a focused professional, I want to filter my list by status and due window so that I can focus on what is actionable today.
- As a focused professional, I want to complete and later reopen a task so that I can correct mistakes without losing history.
- As a focused professional, I want to find a specific task quickly so that I can resume work within seconds.

Acceptance intent (business expectations):
- WHEN a title-only todo is submitted, THE system SHALL create it within 2 seconds and show it in the list.
- WHEN filters for status and due window are applied, THE system SHALL display only matching items consistently within the session.
- WHEN a completed task is reopened, THE system SHALL revert the state and remove completion timestamp immediately.
- WHEN a search-like filter is used, THE system SHALL locate a target item within 5 seconds as perceived by the user.

### Organized Student
- As an organized student, I want to add a due date to assignments so that I can plan ahead.
- As an organized student, I want to see items due this week so that I can balance workload.
- As an organized student, I want to undo a completion so that I can reflect changing requirements.
- As an organized student, I want to avoid losing data on accidental edits or deletions so that I maintain confidence in the system.

Acceptance intent (business expectations):
- WHEN a due date is added, THE system SHALL display the due date according to the user’s time zone.
- WHEN a “this week” filter is set, THE system SHALL return items due within the current week.
- WHEN a completion is undone, THE system SHALL restore state to open and clear the completion timestamp.
- IF a deletion or edit is attempted on another user’s item, THEN THE system SHALL deny and provide a permission message.

### Casual Planner
- As a casual planner, I want minimal required fields so that adding reminders is effortless.
- As a casual planner, I want clear status labels so that I always know whether an item is open or completed.
- As a casual planner, I want to remove clutter quickly so that my list stays manageable.

Acceptance intent (business expectations):
- WHEN only a title is given, THE system SHALL accept it and create the item without requiring optional fields.
- WHEN I mark an item complete, THE system SHALL indicate completion immediately and allow easy reversal.
- WHEN I delete an item, THE system SHALL remove it from active lists right away.

### Support Administrator
- As a support administrator, I want to revoke a user’s sessions so that security incidents can be mitigated quickly.
- As a support administrator, I want to suspend and restore accounts so that policy compliance is enforced.
- As a support administrator, I want visibility into account-level activity so that I can resolve support requests efficiently.

Acceptance intent (business expectations):
- WHEN revoke-all-sessions is executed for a user, THE system SHALL require re-authentication on that user’s devices within 1 minute.
- WHEN an account suspension is applied, THE system SHALL block protected actions until restored.
- WHEN administrative actions occur, THE system SHALL record them for audit.

## Primary Scenarios (Happy Paths)

### Scenario A: First-Time Registration and Email Verification (User)
- Objective: Enable a new user to register and verify ownership of email to start using todoApp.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User provides required registration information (email and password).
  2. System records a new account in unverified state and initiates email verification.
  3. User opens the verification link within its validity window.
  4. System transitions account to verified state; user can sign in and use features.
- Success Criteria: Verification instruction dispatched within 1 minute; account verified within minutes; user can sign in immediately after verification.

### Scenario B: Create a New Todo (User)
- Objective: Allow rapid creation of a minimal todo with optional enrichment.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User initiates creation and supplies a title (mandatory), may add description and due date (optional).
  2. System validates inputs and saves the item as "open".
  3. System associates the item with the creator’s account and sets timestamps.
- Success Criteria: Item appears in the user’s list immediately; optional fields remain optional without blocking.

### Scenario C: Review and Filter Todos (User)
- Objective: View own items and limit the list by status and due date expectations.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User requests their todo list.
  2. System returns items owned by the user with default ordering and business-level filtering controls (e.g., open vs completed).
  3. User applies filters (e.g., show open only, or items due within next 7 days).
- Success Criteria: User finds the intended item within 5 seconds; list reflects filter choices consistently.

### Scenario D: Complete and Reopen a Todo (User)
- Objective: Mark work done, with ability to reverse if needed.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User marks an open item as completed.
  2. System records completion timestamp and sets state to "completed".
  3. If reopened, system removes the completion timestamp and returns state to "open".
- Success Criteria: State changes are instant; history is consistent.

### Scenario E: Edit a Todo (User)
- Objective: Adjust details without causing confusion or loss.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User updates title and/or optional fields.
  2. System validates edits, saves changes, updates last-updated timestamp.
- Success Criteria: Edits reflect immediately and persist across sessions.

### Scenario F: Delete a Todo (User)
- Objective: Remove clutter intentionally and safely.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User requests deletion of one of their items.
  2. System validates ownership and removes the item from active lists.
- Success Criteria: Item no longer appears in active lists; user cannot access deleted item through normal navigation.

### Scenario G: Administrative Session Revocation (Admin)
- Objective: End a user’s active sessions for safety or policy reasons.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. Admin identifies the relevant user account.
  2. Admin initiates revoke-all-sessions for that user.
  3. System invalidates active user sessions.
- Success Criteria: User’s devices require re-authentication; action is auditable.

### Scenario H: Bulk Complete and Reopen (User)
- Objective: Update the state of multiple items efficiently.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User selects up to 50 items.
  2. User triggers bulk complete or bulk reopen.
  3. System applies state changes to all selected items that are eligible.
- Success Criteria: Bulk operation completes within 2 seconds perceived by the user for up to 50 items; partial ineligibility is reported with clear guidance.

### Scenario I: Export My Data (User)
- Objective: Obtain a portable copy of owned todos.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User requests export of own data.
  2. System prepares a complete package of the user’s items and attributes.
  3. System notifies the user when the export is ready.
- Success Criteria: Export includes all owned items and attributes; delivery within a reasonable window as defined in requirements.

### Scenario J: Change Time Zone Preference (User)
- Objective: Ensure dates and times reflect local expectations after a time zone change.
- Steps (business flow):
  1. User changes profile time zone.
  2. System reinterprets and displays due dates and timestamps in the new time zone.
- Success Criteria: Intended due calendar dates remain unchanged; timestamps display consistently in the new time zone.

```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Starts"] --> B["Register Account"]
  B --> C["Email Verification Sent"]
  C --> D{"Verification Link Opened?"}
  D -->|"Yes"| E["Account Verified"]
  D -->|"No"| F["Reminder/Resend Option"]
  E --> G["Create First Todo"]
  G --> H["Review & Filter List"]
  H --> I["Complete Item"]
  I --> J{"Need To Reopen?"}
  J -->|"Yes"| K["Reopen Item"]
  J -->|"No"| L["Continue Working"]
```

Additional lifecycle overview:

```mermaid
graph LR
  U1["Start Authenticated Session"] --> T1["Create Todo"]
  T1 --> T2["Edit Todo"]
  T2 --> T3["Complete Todo"]
  T3 --> Q1{"Reopen Needed?"}
  Q1 -->|"Yes"| T5["Reopen Todo"]
  Q1 -->|"No"| T6["Proceed"]
  T5 --> T2
  T3 --> T7["Delete Todo"]
  T7 --> T8["Removed from Active Views"]
```

## Secondary Scenarios and Edge Cases

- Duplicate Titles:
  - Business Rule: Titles need not be unique; disambiguation is by context and timestamps.
- Title Whitespace and Length:
  - Business Rule: Leading/trailing whitespace is ignored; trimmed length must be within allowed bounds.
- Description Length and Multi-line Text:
  - Business Rule: Long descriptions up to the allowed limit are accepted; line breaks are preserved; executable content is not permitted.
- Due Dates in the Past:
  - Business Rule: Acceptable for historical capture; system reflects overdue status without blocking.
- Daylight Saving Time (DST) and Leap Days:
  - Business Rule: Non-existent times adjust to the next valid time; invalid calendar dates are rejected; due dates represent end-of-day obligations for date-only entries.
- Time Zone Handling:
  - Business Rule: Due date interpretation follows the user’s current time zone; changing time zone re-renders dates without altering intended calendar days.
- Large Lists and Navigation:
  - Business Expectation: Lists are responsive with pagination; ordering defaults are predictable; filters persist during navigation.
- Concurrent Edits and Deletes:
  - Business Rule: Prevent silent overwrites; provide guidance to refresh, reconcile, or retry when conflicts occur; if an item is deleted during edit, inform the user gracefully.
- Session Expiration During Use:
  - Business Rule: Persisted data remains; subsequent protected actions require re-authentication.
- Account Suspension:
  - Business Rule: Suspended accounts cannot perform protected actions; read-only access may be allowed per policy.
- Rate Limiting and Abuse Prevention:
  - Business Rule: Excessive operation frequency may be throttled; communicate limits and retry expectations clearly.
- Export Size and Frequency:
  - Business Rule: Exports may be rate-limited; large exports may be processed asynchronously with notification on completion.
- Accessibility and Clarity:
  - Business Rule: Messages use unambiguous, plain language that directs users toward successful recovery actions.

## Role-based Scenarios (user, admin)

### User Role: Owned-Data Operations
- Create Todo: Creates items with required title and optional fields; items belong exclusively to the creator.
- Read Own Todos: Views only owned items; no leakage of other users’ data.
- Update Own Todos: Edits only owned items; state transitions are controlled (open ⇄ completed).
- Delete Own Todos: Removes only owned items from active lists.
- Export Own Data: Requests export of owned items subject to capacity limits.
- Account Management: Verifies email, signs in/out, changes password, revokes own sessions.

### Admin Role: Support and Policy Enforcement
- Locate and Review User Profile: Finds accounts and reviews business-level details needed for support.
- Revoke User Sessions: Ends all sessions for a user when safety or policy requires; action is auditable.
- Suspend/Restore Account: Changes account status to restrict or restore access as warranted.
- Access Aggregated Indicators: Reviews aggregate-level health indicators without exposing personal content beyond the minimum necessary for support.
- Enforce Policy on Content: Performs support actions on items where justified (e.g., immediate removal of clearly violating content) with audit trail.

## Acceptance Tests in Natural Language (EARS where applicable)

### Registration and Verification
- WHEN a new user submits valid registration information, THE system SHALL create an unverified account and send a verification instruction within 1 minute.
- IF a user opens a valid verification link within its validity window, THEN THE system SHALL mark the account as verified immediately.
- IF a user attempts to sign in before verifying, THEN THE system SHALL prevent access to todo features and direct the user to verify.

### Create Todo
- WHEN a verified user provides a title and submits a new todo, THE system SHALL create the item as "open" and associate it with that user within 2 seconds.
- IF the user omits description and due date, THEN THE system SHALL still create the item without error.
- IF the title length exceeds the business-defined limit, THEN THE system SHALL reject the creation with a clear message referencing the limit.

### Review and Filter
- WHEN a user requests their todo list, THE system SHALL return only items owned by that user ordered by last updated, newest first.
- WHERE a user applies a filter to show only "open" items, THE system SHALL display only items with state "open" consistently across navigation within the same session.
- WHERE a user filters by a due window (today, this week), THE system SHALL compute the window using the user’s time zone and display matching items only.

### Complete and Reopen
- WHEN a user marks an open item as completed, THE system SHALL set the item state to "completed" and record a completion timestamp.
- IF a user reopens a completed item, THEN THE system SHALL remove the completion timestamp and set state to "open".
- IF a user attempts to complete an already completed item, THEN THE system SHALL keep the state unchanged and provide guidance that it is already completed.

### Edit Todo
- WHEN a user updates the title of their own item to a valid value, THE system SHALL save the change and update the last-updated timestamp.
- IF a user attempts to edit another user’s item, THEN THE system SHALL deny the action and inform the user they lack permission.

### Delete Todo
- WHEN a user requests deletion of their own item, THE system SHALL remove the item from active views.
- IF a user attempts to delete an item they do not own, THEN THE system SHALL deny the action and provide a clear permission error message.

### Bulk Operations
- WHEN a user selects up to 50 items and triggers bulk complete, THE system SHALL complete all eligible items within 2 seconds perceived by the user and report any ineligible selections.
- WHEN a user selects up to 50 items and triggers bulk reopen, THE system SHALL reopen all eligible items within 2 seconds perceived by the user and report any ineligible selections.

### Export
- WHEN a user requests export of their own items, THE system SHALL prepare a complete, portable package and notify the user upon completion within a reasonable window.
- IF a user requests export when no items exist, THEN THE system SHALL provide a valid export package indicating zero items.

### Time Zone and Due Dates
- WHILE the user’s time zone setting differs from the time zone at item creation, THE system SHALL preserve the intended due calendar date when displaying the item.
- IF a due date is set in the past, THEN THE system SHALL mark the item as overdue without blocking save operations.
- IF a due date falls into a DST gap in the selected time zone, THEN THE system SHALL adjust to the next valid local time and inform the user.

### Concurrency and Conflicts
- IF two sessions attempt to update the same item concurrently, THEN THE system SHALL prevent silent overwrite and instruct the user to refresh or reconcile.
- IF an item is deleted in another session during an edit attempt, THEN THE system SHALL inform that the item is no longer available and preserve the user’s input locally where feasible.

### Administrative Controls
- WHEN an admin executes revoke-all-sessions for a user, THE system SHALL end the user’s active sessions so that the next action requires re-authentication.
- WHEN an admin suspends a user account, THE system SHALL block access to todo features for that account until restored and record the action for audit.

### Rate Limiting and Recovery
- WHERE a user exceeds defined write operation limits, THE system SHALL throttle further writes temporarily and provide guidance on when to retry.
- WHEN a transient service issue prevents completion of an action, THE system SHALL encourage retry and avoid duplicated creations or updates from a single submitted intent.

## Success Indicators per Scenario

| Scenario | Primary KPI | Target for MVP | Measurement Method |
|---------|-------------|----------------|--------------------|
| Registration & Verification | Verification completion rate within 24 hours | ≥ 80% | Ratio of verified/registered within 24h |
| Create Todo | Median time from intent to saved item | ≤ 10 seconds | Time from create action start to item persistence |
| Review & Filter | Time-to-find (specific item) | ≤ 5 seconds | Time from list request to visibility of targeted item via filters |
| Complete/Reopen | State change latency | ≤ 2 seconds | Time from user action to list reflecting new state |
| Edit Todo | Edit persistence success rate | ≥ 99% | Successful saves / attempts |
| Delete Todo | Erroneous deletions rate | ≤ 0.1% | Confirmed mistaken deletions / deletions |
| Admin Session Revocation | Time to invalidate sessions | ≤ 1 minute | Time from revocation to enforced re-authentication |
| Bulk Complete/Reopen | Completion of eligible items | 100% eligible within 2 seconds | Operation timing and eligibility reporting |
| Export | Export readiness window | ≤ 24 hours (typical) | Time from request to availability notification |
| Time Zone Change | Consistency of due calendar day | 100% preserved | Audit sample of items before/after change |

## References to Related Documents
- See the [Functional Requirements for todoApp](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) for field validations, ownership rules, and acceptance criteria.
- Review the [User Flows for todoApp](./05-todoApp-user-flows.md) for visual flow details complementing these scenarios.
- Consult the [Error Handling and Exception Scenarios for todoApp](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md) for recovery paths and user-facing guidance.

## Scope Clarification
This content provides business requirements, personas, stories, and scenarios for todoApp. It focuses on what the system must do from a user and business perspective and does not prescribe technical implementation. All architecture, API design, and database decisions are at the discretion of the development team.
