files.content:
# todoApp User Flows and Business Process Diagrams

This document provides business requirements only. All technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, and related choices) belong to the development team. The content describes WHAT the system should do, not HOW to build it.

- Service prefix: todoApp
- Roles referenced: user, admin
- Related references for deeper context:
  - See the [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md) for complete role definitions and authentication behaviors.
  - See the [Functional Requirements (MVP)](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) for field-level validations and acceptance criteria.
  - See the [Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md) for comprehensive error taxonomies and user recovery.

## Flow Diagram Conventions

- Orientation: Left-to-right (LR) for all flows.
- Notation: Rectangles represent steps, diamonds represent decisions, rounded shapes represent states or outcomes.
- Labels: All node and edge labels use double quotes; edge labels denote decision outcomes or key information.
- Roles context:
  - "user" refers to an authenticated end user managing their own todos and account.
  - "admin" refers to an administrative user performing oversight or support activities.
- Business semantics:
  - "Create", "Update", "Complete", "Reopen", and "Delete" refer to user-visible actions and their business effects.
  - "Verification" refers to email verification for account activation.
- Performance expectations (user experience level):
  - Simple actions (register, login, create todo, mark complete) should feel immediate. Where stated, response expectations are provided in seconds as testable criteria.

### Visual Legend (Business-Level)

| Symbol | Meaning |
|-------|---------|
| Rectangle | Action or processing step |
| Diamond | Decision point with labeled outcomes |
| Rounded Rectangle | Outcome or state |
| Dotted Arrow | Advisory or guidance path |

## Authentication Flow (register, login, reset)

### Diagram: Registration, Email Verification, Login, Logout, Password Reset (Request + Completion)

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Initiated"
    A1["Open Registration"] --> A2["Enter Email/Password"]
    A3["Open Login"] --> A4["Enter Credentials"]
    A5["Open Password Reset"] --> A6["Submit Reset Request(Email)"]
    A7["Open Logout"] --> A8["Confirm Logout"]
    A9["Open Verification Link"]
    A10["Open Reset Link"] --> A11["Enter New Password"]
  end

  subgraph "Business Processing"
    B1["Validate Registration Input"] --> B2{"Email Available?"}
    B2 -->|"Yes"| B3["Create Account(Pending Verification)"]
    B2 -->|"No"| E1["Inform Duplicate Email"]
    B3 --> B4["Send Verification Email"]

    B5["Validate Credentials"] --> B6{"Account Exists?"}
    B6 -->|"No"| E2["Inform Invalid Login"]
    B6 -->|"Yes"| B7{"Email Verified?"}
    B7 -->|"No"| E3["Inform Verification Required"]
    B7 -->|"Yes"| B8["Establish Session"]

    B9["Validate Reset Request"] --> B10{"Account Exists?"}
    B10 -->|"No"| E4["Inform Generic Confirmation"]
    B10 -->|"Yes"| B11["Send Reset Instructions"]

    B12["Validate Verification Token"] --> B13{"Token Valid?"}
    B13 -->|"Yes"| B14["Activate Account(Verified)"]
    B13 -->|"No"| E5["Inform Invalid/Expired Link"]

    B15["Invalidate Session"]

    B16["Validate Reset Token"] --> B17{"Token Valid?"}
    B17 -->|"Yes"| B18["Validate New Password(Policy)"]
    B18 --> B19{"Valid?"}
    B19 -->|"Yes"| B20["Set New Password & Revoke Sessions"]
    B19 -->|"No"| E6["Inform Password Policy Failure"]
    B17 -->|"No"| E7["Inform Invalid/Expired Reset Link"]
  end

  subgraph "Outcomes"
    C1["Registration Pending"]
    C2["Registration Complete"]
    C3["Logged In"]
    C4["Password Reset Email Sent"]
    C5["Logged Out"]
    C6["Password Reset Complete"]
  end

  %% Flows
  A2 --> B1 --> B2
  B3 --> B4 --> C1

  A9 --> B12 --> B13
  B14 --> C2

  A4 --> B5 --> B6
  B8 --> C3

  A6 --> B9 --> B10
  B11 --> C4

  A8 --> B15 --> C5

  A10 --> B16 --> B17
  B18 --> B19
  B20 --> C6

  %% Errors & Guidance
  E1 -.->|"Guidance: Use Different Email"| A2
  E2 -.->|"Guidance: Retry or Reset"| A3
  E3 -.->|"Guidance: Check Inbox"| C1
  E4 -.->|"Guidance: If No Account, Register"| A1
  E5 -.->|"Guidance: Request New Link"| A5
  E6 -.->|"Guidance: Follow Password Rules"| A11
  E7 -.->|"Guidance: Request New Reset Link"| A5
```

### EARS Requirements — Authentication

- WHEN a person submits valid registration details, THE authentication subsystem SHALL create an account in "pending verification" state and send a verification email within 60 seconds.
- IF the registration email is already in use, THEN THE authentication subsystem SHALL reject the registration and present a message indicating the email is taken.
- WHEN a person clicks a valid verification link, THE authentication subsystem SHALL activate the account immediately and allow login thereafter.
- IF a verification link is invalid or expired, THEN THE authentication subsystem SHALL inform the user and provide a path to request a new link.
- WHEN a verified account submits correct login credentials, THE authentication subsystem SHALL create an authenticated session and reflect the logged-in state within 2 seconds.
- IF login fails due to unknown account or incorrect credentials, THEN THE authentication subsystem SHALL not reveal which field failed and SHALL encourage retry or password reset.
- WHEN a user requests a password reset with an email of an existing account, THE authentication subsystem SHALL send reset instructions within 60 seconds and SHALL not disclose whether the email exists to unauthorized parties.
- WHEN a user opens a valid reset link and enters a new password that meets policy, THE authentication subsystem SHALL set the new password and revoke existing sessions, allowing immediate login with the new password.
- IF a reset link is invalid or expired, THEN THE authentication subsystem SHALL provide a path to request a new reset link without disclosing account existence.
- WHEN a user initiates logout, THE authentication subsystem SHALL terminate the active session immediately and reflect the logged-out state.
- WHERE the actor is an admin assisting a user, THE support process SHALL allow the admin to trigger re-verification or lock/unlock an account according to business policy defined in the role specification and record the reason for audit.
- WHERE excessive failed login attempts occur, THE authentication subsystem SHALL throttle further attempts temporarily and present recovery guidance consistent with the error handling policy.

## Todo Item Lifecycle Flow (create, update, complete, delete)

### Diagram: Todo Item Lifecycle

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Actions"
    T1["Start Create Todo"] --> T2["Enter Title(Optional: Description, Due Date)"]
    T3["Open Todo"] --> T4["Edit Fields"]
    T5["Mark Complete"]
    T6["Reopen Item"]
    T7["Delete Item"]
    T8["List My Todos"]
  end

  subgraph "Business Rules"
    R1["Validate Title(Non-Empty, Max Length)"]
    R2["Validate Optional Fields(Description Length, Due Date Format)"]
    R3{"Item Owned By User?"}
    R4{"Item Editable?"}
    R5{"Item In Active State?"}
    R6{"Item In Completed State?"}
  end

  subgraph "Outcomes"
    O1["Item Created(Active)"]
    O2["Item Updated"]
    O3["Item Completed"]
    O4["Item Reopened(Active)"]
    O5["Item Deleted(Permanent)"]
    O6["User List Returned"]
  end

  %% Creation
  T2 --> R1 --> R2 --> O1

  %% Read/List
  T8 --> O6

  %% Update
  T4 --> R3
  R3 -->|"Yes"| R4
  R3 -->|"No"| E1["Inform Access Denied"]
  R4 -->|"Yes"| O2
  R4 -->|"No"| E2["Inform Not Editable"]

  %% Complete
  T5 --> R3
  R3 -->|"Yes"| R5
  R5 -->|"Yes"| O3
  R5 -->|"No"| E3["Inform Already Completed or Invalid State"]

  %% Reopen
  T6 --> R3
  R3 -->|"Yes"| R6
  R6 -->|"Yes"| O4
  R6 -->|"No"| E4["Inform Not Completed"]

  %% Delete
  T7 --> R3
  R3 -->|"Yes"| O5
  R3 -->|"No"| E5["Inform Access Denied"]

  %% Guidance
  E1 -.->|"Guidance: Operate Only Own Items"| T3
  E2 -.->|"Guidance: Check State/Fields"| T3
  E3 -.->|"Guidance: No Duplicate Completion"| T3
  E4 -.->|"Guidance: Reopen Only Completed"| T3
  E5 -.->|"Guidance: Ownership Required"| T3
```

### EARS Requirements — Todo Lifecycle

- THE todo management subsystem SHALL require a non-empty title up to the maximum length defined in the functional specification.
- WHERE a description is provided, THE todo management subsystem SHALL accept it up to the maximum length defined in the functional specification.
- WHERE a due date is provided, THE todo management subsystem SHALL interpret it using the user’s locale and time zone settings as specified in the functional specification.
- WHEN a user creates a valid todo, THE todo management subsystem SHALL place it in the "active" state and make it available in the user’s list immediately.
- WHEN a user requests to list their todos, THE todo management subsystem SHALL return only items owned by that user, ordered by the current business sorting rule.
- IF a user attempts to modify a todo they do not own, THEN THE todo management subsystem SHALL deny the action and present an authorization message without exposing other users’ data.
- WHEN a user edits fields of a todo, THE todo management subsystem SHALL apply the changes immediately if all validations pass and SHALL update the last-updated indicator.
- WHEN a user marks an active todo as complete, THE todo management subsystem SHALL update its state to "completed" and display the completion timestamp according to the user’s time zone.
- IF a user attempts to complete a todo already in "completed" state, THEN THE todo management subsystem SHALL inform that the item is already completed and SHALL not change state.
- WHEN a user reopens a completed todo, THE todo management subsystem SHALL return it to the "active" state and clear any derived completion indicators while preserving historical metadata as defined in the business rules.
- WHEN a user deletes their own todo, THE todo management subsystem SHALL remove it from the user’s list permanently for MVP scope.
- WHERE an admin performs moderation, THE administrative process SHALL not alter user todo content except when enforcing policy; any such action SHALL be auditable according to the role specification.

## Error and Recovery Flow

### Diagram: Error Categories and Recovery Paths

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Operation Context"
    U1["Attempt Operation"] --> D1{"Auth Error?"}
  end

  subgraph "Authentication/Authorization"
    D1 -->|"Yes"| A1["Show Auth Message"]
    A1 --> A2{"User Intends to Recover?"}
    A2 -->|"Yes"| A3["Prompt Login or Verify Email"]
    A2 -->|"No"| A4["Abort Operation"]
  end

  subgraph "Validation"
    D1 -->|"No"| D2{"Validation Error?"}
    D2 -->|"Yes"| V1["Show Field Guidance"]
    V1 --> V2{"Can Retry Immediately?"}
    V2 -->|"Yes"| V3["Allow Correction and Resubmission"]
    V2 -->|"No"| V4["Provide Instructions"]
  end

  subgraph "Not Found / Conflict"
    D2 -->|"No"| D3{"Not Found?"}
    D3 -->|"Yes"| N1["Inform Missing Resource"]
    D3 -->|"No"| D4{"Conflict?"}
    D4 -->|"Yes"| C1["Inform Concurrent Update"]
    C1 --> C2["Offer Refresh or Retry"]
  end

  subgraph "Rate Limit / Service Unavailable"
    D4 -->|"No"| D5{"Rate Limited?"}
    D5 -->|"Yes"| R1["Show Wait Guidance"]
    D5 -->|"No"| D6{"Service Unavailable?"}
    D6 -->|"Yes"| S1["Show Retry Later Guidance"]
    D6 -->|"No"| S2["Proceed to Success"]
  end
```

### EARS Requirements — Error and Recovery

- WHEN an action requires authentication and the user is not authenticated, THE system SHALL present a message to log in or verify and SHALL not proceed with the action.
- IF a form submission contains invalid fields, THEN THE system SHALL highlight the specific fields and provide actionable guidance for correction.
- WHEN a missing resource is referenced (e.g., deleted or non-existent todo), THE system SHALL inform the absence without exposing whether the resource ever existed for other users.
- IF a concurrency conflict occurs due to simultaneous updates, THEN THE system SHALL prevent data loss by rejecting the later change and SHALL offer a path to refresh and retry.
- WHEN a user exceeds allowed operation frequency, THE system SHALL inform that the rate limit has been reached and SHALL advise when to try again.
- IF a transient service disruption prevents completing an action, THEN THE system SHALL inform the user and encourage retry after a short interval without blaming user input.
- WHERE an account is suspended due to policy, THE system SHALL block protected actions and present suspension information upon next sign-in attempt.

## State Model for Todo Items

### Diagram: States and Transitions (Business-Level)

```mermaid
graph LR
  S0["Nonexistent"] -->|"Create"| S1["Active"]
  S1 -->|"Update Fields"| S1
  S1 -->|"Complete"| S2["Completed"]
  S2 -->|"Reopen"| S1
  S1 -->|"Delete"| S3["Deleted(Permanent)"]
  S2 -->|"Delete"| S3
```

### EARS Requirements — State Model

- THE todo item lifecycle SHALL consist of "active", "completed", and "deleted" states for MVP.
- WHEN a todo is created successfully, THE lifecycle SHALL enter the "active" state.
- WHEN a todo is marked complete from the "active" state, THE lifecycle SHALL transition to "completed" without modifying non-edited fields.
- WHEN a completed todo is reopened, THE lifecycle SHALL transition back to "active" and clear completion-specific indicators while keeping other fields intact.
- WHEN a todo is deleted, THE lifecycle SHALL transition to "deleted" and SHALL not be available in the user’s list thereafter for MVP.

## Narrative Descriptions of Each Flow

### Authentication Flow Narrative

- Registration and Verification
  - Trigger: A person attempts to create an account with an email and password.
  - Decision: If the email is already in use, the registration is rejected and guidance is provided to try another email. Otherwise, the account is created in a pending verification state, and a verification message is sent.
  - Outcome: On clicking a valid verification link, the account becomes verified and eligible for login.
  - Non-disclosure: Do not reveal whether a specific email exists to unauthorized parties.
  - Resend: If the verification link expires, a resend request is available within policy limits.

- Login and Session Establishment
  - Trigger: A verified user enters credentials.
  - Decision: If credentials are invalid or the account is unverified, the login is denied with appropriate guidance. Otherwise, a session is established.
  - Outcome: The user reaches the authenticated state capable of performing todo operations.
  - Protection: Repeated failed attempts are throttled with clear recovery guidance.

- Password Reset
  - Request: Any person may initiate a reset request by providing an email; confirmation messaging does not disclose account existence.
  - Completion: A person opening a valid reset link provides a new password that meets policy, resulting in session revocation and the ability to log in immediately.
  - Recovery: Invalid or expired reset links result in guidance to request a new link.

- Logout
  - Trigger: A logged-in user initiates logout.
  - Outcome: The active session is terminated immediately and the user returns to a non-authenticated state.

- Admin Support Notes
  - Admins can enforce policies such as locking accounts or re-triggering verification within the constraints and audit expectations defined in the role specification.

### Todo Item Lifecycle Narrative

- Create
  - Trigger: An authenticated user initiates creation.
  - Validation: Title must be present and within allowed length; optional description and due date, when provided, must meet length and format rules.
  - Outcome: A new todo is created in the active state and appears in the user’s list.

- Read
  - Trigger: A user lists or views their todos.
  - Authorization: Items are only visible to their owner. Admin oversight of content, when necessary for policy enforcement, is controlled and auditable.

- Update
  - Trigger: A user edits fields of their own todo.
  - Decision: If the item is not owned by the user, the operation is denied. If the item is in a state that disallows the requested change (as per business rules), the operation is denied with guidance. Otherwise, the update is applied and the last-updated indicator changes.

- Complete
  - Trigger: A user marks an active todo as complete.
  - Decision: If already completed, the operation is rejected with guidance.
  - Outcome: Item moves to completed state; completion timestamp is recorded for display based on the user’s time zone.

- Reopen
  - Trigger: A user reopens a completed item.
  - Outcome: Item moves back to active state; completion-specific indicators are cleared while preserving other details.

- Delete
  - Trigger: A user deletes their own item.
  - Outcome: Item is permanently removed from the user’s list for MVP. Future phases may introduce trash/restore according to the business rules document versioning.

### Error and Recovery Narrative

- Authentication and Authorization Errors
  - Scenario: User attempts actions requiring authentication or proper authorization.
  - Response: The system blocks the action and presents clear next steps: log in, verify email, or request access as appropriate. No sensitive details are disclosed.

- Validation Errors
  - Scenario: User submissions fail validations (e.g., missing title, invalid due date format, overly long text fields).
  - Response: The system identifies specific fields and provides actionable guidance to correct and resubmit while preserving valid inputs.

- Not Found
  - Scenario: A referenced todo does not exist or is no longer available.
  - Response: The system informs that the resource is unavailable without exposing historical existence for other users.

- Conflict (Concurrent Updates)
  - Scenario: Two edits occur to the same todo in close succession.
  - Response: The system prevents overwriting by rejecting the later change, guiding the user to refresh and retry; options for reconcile/overwrite/discard are governed by the error handling policy.

- Rate Limit
  - Scenario: Excessive operations in a short period (e.g., repeated create/delete).
  - Response: The system asks the user to slow down and to try again after a provided interval, describing the applicable limit window in user terms.

- Service Unavailable
  - Scenario: Temporary outage or degraded service prevents operation completion.
  - Response: The system encourages retry after a short interval and provides reassurance without implying user error; user-entered data is preserved when feasible for later submission.

## Additional EARS Requirements Spanning Flows

- WHILE a user is authenticated, THE system SHALL maintain a valid session and reflect authorization according to the role’s business permissions.
- WHERE the actor is "admin", THE system SHALL allow actions aligned with oversight and policy enforcement while maintaining auditability and minimal data exposure.
- WHEN business limits are exceeded (such as rate limits), THE system SHALL communicate the limit and the time window for retry in user terms.
- WHEN time-sensitive information is presented (such as due dates and completion timestamps), THE system SHALL align display and interpretation with the user’s configured time zone and locale rules defined in the functional specification.
- WHEN a user signs out voluntarily or due to security action, THE system SHALL invalidate the current session and require re-authentication for protected actions.
- IF an account is suspended for policy reasons, THEN THE system SHALL block protected actions and present suspension messaging at the next sign-in attempt.

## Traceability and References

- Authentication details and lifecycle expectations: [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md).
- Feature-level behaviors and validations: [Functional Requirements (MVP)](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md).
- Error handling categories and user-facing guidance: [Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md).

End of document.

What limits, if any, exist for operations?
How are conflicts in rules resolved?
constraints: Express rules in testable, measurable terms (use EARS where applicable)
Avoid any database, API, or technical design details
files.content:
# todoApp Business Rules and Constraints

## Purpose and Scope
Provides business rules, validations, constraints, and state logic for todoApp to ensure consistent behavior across all features and scenarios. Describes WHAT must happen from a business perspective; technical implementation details (architecture, APIs, database design, storage, libraries) are at the discretion of the development team.

Scope includes: todo item field validations, item state transitions, ownership and access rules, rate limits and operational constraints, retention and deletion behaviors, time zone and date handling, idempotency and concurrency policies, conflict resolution principles, and traceability to related specifications. Applies to roles: user and admin.

Related documents for broader context:
- Refer to the [Functional Requirements for todoApp](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) for end-to-end feature behaviors and acceptance criteria.
- Refer to the [Non-Functional Requirements for todoApp](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md) for performance, security, and reliability expectations.
- Refer to the [Data Lifecycle and Privacy Requirements for todoApp](./09-todoApp-data-lifecycle-and-privacy.md) for conceptual lifecycle and privacy constraints.

## Terminology and States
- Owner: The authenticated account that created a todo item. Each item has exactly one Owner.
- Todo Item (Item): A task record with a required title and optional attributes such as description and due date.
- Active: The normal state of an Item that is not completed and not in trash.
- Completed: The state indicating the Item has been marked done.
- Trashed: The state indicating the Item has been deleted by the Owner but is recoverable within the trash retention period.
- Purged: The state indicating the Item has been irreversibly removed following retention rules.
- Suspension: An account-level restriction under which write operations are blocked.

### State Model and Allowed Transitions
Item states and transitions follow the flow below.

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Todo Item States"
    A["Active"] --> B["Completed"]
    B --> A
    A --> C["Trashed"]
    B --> C
    C --> A
    C --> D["Purged(Irreversible)"]
  end
```

- Allowed transitions: Active → Completed; Completed → Active (reopen); Active → Trashed; Completed → Trashed; Trashed → Active (restore); Trashed → Purged.
- Disallowed transitions: Any direct transition to Purged except from Trashed; Purged has no outgoing transitions.

EARS:
- THE todoApp SHALL constrain Item transitions to those shown in the state model.
- IF an Item is in "Purged", THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent any further operations on that Item.

## Todo Item Validation Rules
Defines required and optional fields, permitted value ranges, and behavioral validations for creation, updates, completion, reopening, and deletion. All limits are measured after trimming leading and trailing whitespace where applicable.

### Field-Level Constraints
- Title (required):
  - Length: 1 to 120 Unicode characters after trimming.
  - Content: No control characters; line breaks permitted and normalized.
  - Uniqueness: Not required; duplicate titles are allowed.
- Description (optional):
  - Length: 0 to 1,000 Unicode characters after trimming.
  - Content: May include line breaks; no active scripts or executable content; no embedded markup execution.
- Due Date (optional):
  - Type: Either date-only (no time) or date-time (explicit local time semantics).
  - Range: Not earlier than the Item’s creation date in the user’s local time; not later than 5 years from the current date in the user’s local time.
  - Date-only semantics: Interpreted as due at 23:59:59 in the user’s time zone on that calendar date.
  - Date-time semantics: Interpreted as an exact clock time in the user’s time zone.

EARS (creation/update validation):
- WHEN an Item is created, THE todoApp SHALL reject titles that are fewer than 1 or greater than 120 characters after trimming.
- WHEN an Item is created or updated, THE todoApp SHALL reject descriptions longer than 1,000 characters after trimming.
- WHEN a Due Date is provided, THE todoApp SHALL interpret date-only values as due at 23:59:59 in the user’s time zone on that date.
- WHEN a Due Date is provided, THE todoApp SHALL reject values earlier than the Item’s creation date or more than 5 years in the future (user-local).
- IF a field contains control characters or executable content, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the operation and indicate the invalid field.

### Behavioral Validations
- Completion and Reopening:
  - An Item can be marked Completed only from Active.
  - A Completed Item can be reopened only back to Active.
- Deletion (Trash) and Purge:
  - Only Items in Active or Completed can be moved to Trashed.
  - Purge is allowed only from Trashed per retention rules.

EARS (state validations):
- WHEN a user marks an Active Item as Completed, THE todoApp SHALL set it to Completed and record the completion timestamp.
- IF a user attempts to mark a Completed Item as Completed again, THEN THE todoApp SHALL take no state change and inform the user the Item is already Completed.
- WHEN a user reopens a Completed Item, THE todoApp SHALL move it to Active and clear the completion timestamp.
- IF a user attempts to purge an Item not in Trashed, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny the operation.

### Concurrency, Integrity, and Idempotency (business perspective)
- Edit consistency: Edits must not silently overwrite more recent changes made by the Owner in another session.
- Idempotency: Repeated submissions of the same action within a short interval should not create duplicated Items or double-apply state transitions.

EARS (concurrency & idempotency):
- IF a concurrent modification is detected during update, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent the overwrite and require the user to retry with the latest version.
- WHEN an Item is restored from Trashed, THE todoApp SHALL ensure it re-enters Active with all fields preserved as of the time of trashing.
- WHERE a create action is retried due to transient conditions, THE todoApp SHALL avoid duplicate Items resulting from the same user action.
- WHERE a state-change action (complete/reopen) is repeated without intervening changes, THE todoApp SHALL keep the Item’s state consistent and avoid double application.

## Ownership and Access Rules
Roles: user (standard account) and admin (administrative oversight under policy). Access rules are expressed from a business and privacy standpoint.

### Core Ownership Rules
- Each Item has exactly one Owner, which is the creating user account.
- Owners can create, read, update, complete/reopen, trash, restore, and purge their own Items subject to other rules herein.
- Cross-user access is not permitted for users.

### Administrative Access (Support and Policy)
- Admins may access a user’s Items only for legitimate support, security, or policy enforcement, with justification and audit logging.
- Admin operations follow least-privilege: minimum actions necessary for the case and only for the minimum time required.

EARS (access control):
- WHEN a user requests to read an Item, THE todoApp SHALL allow access only if the user is the Owner or an admin has an active support scope for that user.
- IF a user attempts to read or modify an Item that they do not own, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny the operation without revealing the Item’s existence.
- WHERE an admin has an active support scope for a user, THE todoApp SHALL allow admin read and write actions limited to the scope duration and case context and SHALL record justification in audit data.
- WHILE an account is under Suspension, THE todoApp SHALL block write operations for that account and allow reads of owned Items.
- IF an account is deleted, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent any further access to Items previously owned by that account and apply retention rules.

## Rate Limits and Operational Constraints (business-level)
Limits protect system integrity, reduce abuse, and ensure predictable performance. Limits are measured per user account unless stated otherwise and align to non-functional targets.

### Per-Operation and Aggregate Frequency Limits
- Aggregate write operations (create/update/complete/reopen/trash/restore/purge): up to 60 actions per minute in rolling windows.
- Aggregate read operations (list/detail/filter): up to 120 actions per minute in rolling windows.
- Optional finer bounds for user experience consistency:
  - Create Item: up to 30 per minute.
  - Complete/Reopen: up to 60 per minute.
  - Purge: up to 30 per minute.

### Inventory and Size Limits
- Maximum concurrent Items per user (all states except Purged): 10,000.
- Pagination sizes: 10, 20, 50, or 100 items per page; default 20.
- Bulk operations (interactive): up to 50 Items per action (e.g., bulk complete/reopen/purge) to preserve responsiveness.

### Validation and Responsiveness Expectations (business-level)
- Single-field validation feedback should be perceived as immediate for typical inputs and SHALL align with non-functional performance targets.

EARS (limits & operational constraints):
- WHERE a user exceeds aggregate write limits, THE todoApp SHALL throttle further writes until the window resets and inform the user of the limit.
- WHERE a user exceeds aggregate read limits, THE todoApp SHALL throttle further reads until the window resets and inform the user of the limit.
- IF a user attempts to create an Item when they already have 10,000 non-Purged Items, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the creation and indicate the capacity limit.
- WHERE a bulk operation exceeds the interactive limit of 50 Items, THE todoApp SHALL process the excess via an alternative path or require the user to split the operation.

## Retention and Deletion Rules
Governs how Items are retained, restored, and permanently removed (see also the [Data Lifecycle and Privacy Requirements](./09-todoApp-data-lifecycle-and-privacy.md)).

### Trash Retention
- Trashed Items are retained for 30 calendar days from the time of trashing.
- Restoration returns the Item to Active with its previous content intact.

### Purging
- Automatic purge: Items in Trashed are automatically purged after 30 days.
- Manual purge: The Owner may manually purge a Trashed Item at any time before automatic purge.
- Purge is irreversible and removes the Item from user-accessible views and recovery.

### Account Deletion and Suspension
- Account deletion: All Items owned by the account enter Trashed immediately and follow a shortened retention of 7 days before automatic purge.
- Legal hold: Admins may place a legal or policy hold that prevents purge until the hold is cleared.
- Suspension: Suspended accounts cannot modify Items; retention timelines continue to elapse normally.

EARS (retention & deletion):
- WHEN an Item enters Trashed, THE todoApp SHALL set a purge-after timestamp of 30 calendar days from the time of trashing.
- IF the number of non-Purged Items exceeds 10,000 for a user, THEN THE todoApp SHALL purge the oldest Trashed Items first until the cap is satisfied.
- WHEN an account is deleted, THE todoApp SHALL move all owned Items to Trashed and set a purge-after timestamp of 7 calendar days.
- IF a legal hold exists on an Item, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent purge until the hold is removed.
- WHEN a user restores a Trashed Item, THE todoApp SHALL remove the purge-after timestamp and return the Item to Active.

## Time Zone and Date Handling Rules
Ensures consistent user-local behavior for dates and times while avoiding reliance on device-specific interpretations.

### User-Local Semantics
- Date-only due dates: Treated as due at 23:59:59 on that calendar date in the user’s selected time zone.
- Date-time due dates: Interpreted as exact local times in the user’s selected time zone.
- Default time zone: When no preferred time zone is set, use a reasonable default aligned with the user’s locale; for MVP, Asia/Seoul (KST, UTC+9) is the default baseline.

### Daylight Saving Time (DST) and Calendar Rules
- DST forward transition (e.g., 01:59:59 → 03:00:00): A local time that does not exist is adjusted to the next valid local time on that date.
- DST backward transition (hour repeats): A local time in the repeated hour is interpreted as the first occurrence unless the user specifies otherwise.
- Leap years and month length: Invalid calendar dates are rejected.

EARS (time zone & calendar):
- WHEN interpreting a date-only due date, THE todoApp SHALL treat it as due at 23:59:59 in the user’s time zone on that date.
- IF a provided local time falls into a DST gap, THEN THE todoApp SHALL adjust it to the next valid local time on the same date and inform the user.
- IF a provided date is not a valid calendar date, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject it and indicate the invalid field.

## Account-Level Validation Rules (business)
Constraints for account data relevant to using todoApp features.

- Display Name (optional): 1 to 80 Unicode characters after trimming; no control characters.
- Email (required for registration): Must be unique per account under todoApp policies.
- Password (required for registration): Minimum 12 characters; at least three of the following categories: uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, special characters; banned-password list enforced; prevent reuse of the last 5 passwords; no spaces at either end after trimming.
- Email Verification: Accounts may create and manage Items according to policy; sensitive account changes and recovery communications require a verified email.

EARS (account-level):
- WHEN registering, THE todoApp SHALL reject passwords shorter than 12 characters or lacking at least three of the four required character categories.
- WHEN registering with an email already in use, THE todoApp SHALL reject the registration and indicate that the email is taken.
- WHERE an account email is unverified, THE todoApp SHALL restrict recovery communications and sensitive account actions until verification is completed.
- WHERE a new password matches one of the previous 5 passwords, THE todoApp SHALL reject the change and require a different password.

## Rule Conflict Resolution and Precedence
Resolves conflicts between rules or between rules and context-specific conditions via defined precedence.

### Precedence Order
1. Legal/Compliance obligations (e.g., legal holds, court orders)
2. Security and Privacy policies (e.g., least-privilege, non-disclosure of existence)
3. Account status constraints (e.g., suspension, deletion)
4. Ownership rules
5. Retention and deletion rules
6. Rate limits and operational constraints
7. User preferences (e.g., time zone selection)

EARS (precedence):
- IF a legal hold conflicts with a retention rule, THEN THE todoApp SHALL honor the legal hold and defer purge.
- IF a suspension conflicts with a user’s attempt to modify an Item, THEN THE todoApp SHALL enforce the suspension and deny the modification.
- WHERE a privacy policy conflicts with an error message that would reveal existence of another user’s Item, THE todoApp SHALL prioritize privacy and not disclose existence.

### Examples
- Privacy vs. Access Inquiry: If a user tries to open another user’s Item by ID, do not reveal whether it exists; respond as if inaccessible.
- Rate Limit vs. Urgent Purge: If a purge request exceeds the allowed rate, queue or require retry while ensuring the user can eventually complete the purge.
- Ownership vs. Admin Oversight: Allow admin access only with explicit, time-limited support scope and justification recorded in audit data.

## Traceability to Functional Requirements
Links rule groups to relevant sections of related documents to ensure testability and cross-reference.

| Business Rule Area | Related Functional Section | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Field validations (title, description, due date) | [Todo Item Management in Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) | Create/update acceptance criteria must align |
| State transitions (complete, reopen, trash, restore, purge) | [Completion and Reopening in Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) | Transitions mirror acceptance tests; retention aligns with data lifecycle |
| Ownership and access | [Data Ownership and Privacy Rules in Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) | Must be consistent with role capabilities |
| Rate limits and item caps | [Business Constraints and Limits in Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) | Limits are measurable and enforceable |
| Retention and deletion | [Data Lifecycle and Privacy Requirements](./09-todoApp-data-lifecycle-and-privacy.md) | Trash retention and purge windows |
| Time zone and date handling | [Non-Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md) | Local-time correctness and perceived responsiveness |
| Account-level rules | [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md) | Password and email uniqueness behaviors |

## Consolidated EARS Index (for test design)
- THE todoApp SHALL constrain Item transitions to those shown in the state model.
- IF an Item is in "Purged", THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent any further operations on that Item.
- WHEN an Item is created, THE todoApp SHALL reject titles that are fewer than 1 or greater than 120 characters after trimming.
- WHEN an Item is created or updated, THE todoApp SHALL reject descriptions longer than 1,000 characters after trimming.
- WHEN a Due Date is provided, THE todoApp SHALL interpret date-only values as due at 23:59:59 in the user’s time zone on that date.
- WHEN a Due Date is provided, THE todoApp SHALL reject values earlier than the Item’s creation date or more than 5 years in the future (user-local).
- IF a field contains control characters or executable content, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the operation and indicate the invalid field.
- WHEN a user marks an Active Item as Completed, THE todoApp SHALL set it to Completed and record the completion timestamp.
- IF a user attempts to mark a Completed Item as Completed again, THEN THE todoApp SHALL take no state change and inform the user the Item is already Completed.
- WHEN a user reopens a Completed Item, THE todoApp SHALL move it to Active and clear the completion timestamp.
- IF a user attempts to purge an Item not in Trashed, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny the operation.
- IF a concurrent modification is detected during update, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent the overwrite and require the user to retry with the latest version.
- WHEN an Item is restored from Trashed, THE todoApp SHALL ensure it re-enters Active with all fields preserved as of the time of trashing.
- WHERE a create action is retried due to transient conditions, THE todoApp SHALL avoid duplicate Items resulting from the same user action.
- WHERE a state-change action is repeated without intervening changes, THE todoApp SHALL keep the Item’s state consistent and avoid double application.
- WHEN a user requests to read an Item, THE todoApp SHALL allow access only if the user is the Owner or an admin has an active support scope for that user.
- IF a user attempts to read or modify an Item they do not own, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny the operation without revealing the Item’s existence.
- WHERE an admin has an active support scope for a user, THE todoApp SHALL allow admin actions limited to scope and duration and SHALL record justification in audit data.
- WHILE an account is under Suspension, THE todoApp SHALL block write operations for that account and allow reads of owned Items.
- IF an account is deleted, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent any further access to Items previously owned by that account and apply retention rules.
- WHERE a user exceeds aggregate write limits, THE todoApp SHALL throttle writes until the window resets and inform the user of the limit.
- WHERE a user exceeds aggregate read limits, THE todoApp SHALL throttle reads until the window resets and inform the user of the limit.
- IF a user attempts to create an Item when they already have 10,000 non-Purged Items, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the creation and indicate the capacity limit.
- WHERE a bulk operation exceeds 50 Items, THE todoApp SHALL process the excess via an alternative path or require the user to split the operation.
- WHEN an Item enters Trashed, THE todoApp SHALL set a purge-after timestamp of 30 calendar days from the time of trashing.
- IF the number of non-Purged Items exceeds 10,000 for a user, THEN THE todoApp SHALL purge the oldest Trashed Items first until the cap is satisfied.
- WHEN an account is deleted, THE todoApp SHALL move all owned Items to Trashed and set a purge-after timestamp of 7 calendar days.
- IF a legal hold exists on an Item, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent purge until the hold is removed.
- WHEN a user restores a Trashed Item, THE todoApp SHALL remove the purge-after timestamp and return the Item to Active.
- WHEN interpreting a date-only due date, THE todoApp SHALL treat it as due at 23:59:59 in the user’s time zone on that date.
- IF a provided local time falls into a DST gap, THEN THE todoApp SHALL adjust it to the next valid local time on the same date and inform the user.
- IF a provided date is not a valid calendar date, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject it and indicate the invalid field.
- WHEN registering, THE todoApp SHALL reject passwords shorter than 12 characters or lacking at least three of the four character categories.
- WHEN registering with an email already in use, THE todoApp SHALL reject the registration and indicate that the email is taken.
- WHERE an account email is unverified, THE todoApp SHALL restrict recovery communications and sensitive account actions until verification is completed.
- WHERE a new password matches one of the previous 5 passwords, THE todoApp SHALL reject the change and require a different password.
- IF a legal hold conflicts with a retention rule, THEN THE todoApp SHALL honor the legal hold and defer purge.
- IF a suspension conflicts with a user’s attempt to modify an Item, THEN THE todoApp SHALL enforce the suspension and deny the modification.
- WHERE a privacy policy conflicts with an error message that would reveal existence of another user’s Item, THE todoApp SHALL prioritize privacy and not disclose existence.

## Success Criteria
Implementation is considered successful when:
- All EARS statements herein pass acceptance tests defined in related documents.
- Item state transitions are exactly as modeled and enforced in all features.
- Validation and limit rules produce consistent, user-understandable outcomes across the system.
- Retention and purge behaviors match specified timelines, including account deletion variations and legal holds.
- Time zone and DST handling provide correct, predictable due date semantics in user-local time.
- Idempotency prevents duplicated effects from repeated user submissions.

End of document.

outline: Error Taxonomy (Authentication, Authorization, Validation, Not Found, Conflict, Rate Limit, Service Unavailable)

keyQuestions: What errors can occur and how should the system respond for the user?

files.content:
# todoApp Error Handling and Exception Scenarios

## Introduction and Scope
Business-level error handling and exception scenarios govern how todoApp behaves under failure from the user’s perspective. Responses include clear messages, actionable guidance, and safe recovery paths that protect user intent and data. Policies below set auditing and monitoring expectations in business terms. Content describes WHAT the system must do in failure conditions, not HOW to implement it.

Related references for context:
- [User Roles and Authentication Requirements for todoApp](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md)
- [Functional Requirements for todoApp](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md)
- [User Flows for todoApp](./05-todoApp-user-flows.md)
- [Non-Functional Requirements for todoApp](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md)

## Error Taxonomy
Errors are grouped into seven user-facing categories. Each category includes representative scenarios, causes, and business expectations for messaging and recovery.

### 1) Authentication Errors
Definition: Failures related to verifying identity or session validity.
Examples:
- Invalid email or password during sign-in.
- Attempt to sign in while email remains unverified where verification is required.
- Expired or invalid session when accessing protected features.
- Global logout invoked by the same user resulting in session revocation.
Business expectations:
- Provide neutral, clear messaging without exposing sensitive details.
- Guide immediate next steps such as retrying, verifying email, or signing in again.

### 2) Authorization Errors
Definition: Authenticated identity lacks permission for the requested action.
Examples:
- Attempt to access another user’s todo item.
- Attempt to perform administrative actions without the admin role.
Business expectations:
- State that the action is not permitted without confirming whether the resource exists.
- Offer safe alternatives (e.g., return to the user’s list, contact support via approved channels).

### 3) Validation Errors
Definition: Submitted input fails business rules.
Representative rules (aligned with functional and business rules):
- Title: required, 1–120 characters (trimmed).
- Description: optional, up to 1,000 characters.
- Due date: optional; if present, must be a valid calendar date-time and not earlier than the creation date in the user’s time zone; not more than 5 years in the future.
- Completion actions: only allowed on existing, owned items in a valid state for the transition.
Business expectations:
- Identify each invalid field with a specific reason and a concrete correction.
- Preserve valid portions of user input where safe.

### 4) Not Found Errors
Definition: Requested resource does not exist or is not available to the requesting user.
Examples:
- Todo item was deleted or is owned by someone else.
- Link to an item after the owner’s account was deleted.
Business expectations:
- Communicate unavailability without confirming ownership or prior existence.
- Offer navigation to a safe context (e.g., the user’s list) or a refresh suggestion.

### 5) Conflict Errors
Definition: Requested change conflicts with the current resource state.
Examples:
- Concurrent update: another session or device modified the item between read and write.
- State conflict: attempting a transition inconsistent with the latest state.
Business expectations:
- Prevent silent overwrites and provide a guided reconciliation path.
- Offer clear options that minimize unintended data loss.

### 6) Rate Limit Errors
Definition: Action frequency exceeds business-defined safe thresholds.
Examples:
- Excessive create/update/delete operations within a short period.
- Excessive sign-in attempts.
Business expectations:
- Communicate that limits have been reached, the approximate wait before retry, and safe alternatives.

### 7) Service Unavailable / Degraded Errors
Definition: Temporary unavailability or degraded capability of part or all of the service.
Examples:
- Planned maintenance window.
- Transient upstream issue or partial feature outage.
Business expectations:
- Provide a concise status message and retry guidance.
- Preserve user-entered data when feasible so users can retry later.

## User-Facing Messages and Guidance
Messages are short, neutral, and action-oriented. Each includes a succinct title or first sentence, a brief explanation, and a specific next step. Messages avoid technical jargon and do not disclose security-sensitive details. Tone remains consistent across categories.

Canonical message examples (business-level, localization-ready):
- Authentication (invalid credentials): "We couldn’t sign you in. Check your email and password and try again."
- Authentication (verification required): "Please verify your email to continue. We’ve sent a verification message to your inbox."
- Authentication (session expired): "Your session has ended. Sign in again to continue."
- Authorization: "You don’t have permission to do that."
- Validation (title missing): "Title is required and must be between 1 and 120 characters."
- Validation (due date): "Due date must be valid and not earlier than the creation date."
- Not Found: "This item is no longer available."
- Conflict: "This item changed elsewhere. Review updates before saving."
- Rate Limit: "You’ve reached the limit for this action. Please wait a moment and try again."
- Service Unavailable: "We’re having trouble right now. Please try again shortly."

Guidance patterns:
- Offer safe navigation (e.g., return to my list) rather than exposing internal details.
- Preserve unsaved input locally where feasible to honor user intent after recovery.
- Indicate approximate wait times in natural language (e.g., "about a minute") when limits or maintenance apply.

## Recovery and Retry Policies
Behavior under failure aims to preserve user intent and minimize repeated effort.

General recovery principles:
- Preserve user intent by maintaining entered data locally where safe.
- Encourage low-effort retries; if an action is safe to retry, provide a one-step retry affordance.
- Spread retries to avoid repeated failures and improve success likelihood.
- Ensure that repeated submissions do not create duplicates or repeated side effects from the user’s perspective.

Category-specific expectations:
- Authentication
  - Invalid credentials: allow immediate retry after correction.
  - Unverified email: guide to verification; allow retry after verification completes.
  - Session expired: prompt sign-in; upon success, return the user to the prior action context.
- Authorization
  - Do not retry until permissions change; route the user to a safe context.
- Validation
  - Allow immediate retry after correcting invalid fields; preserve all valid entries.
- Not Found
  - Do not encourage retry; guide to a safe context. If the user expects the item to exist (e.g., just created), suggest refreshing the list.
- Conflict
  - Offer reconciliation as described in the conflict section.
- Rate Limit
  - Communicate the minimum wait before the next attempt, using natural language.
- Service Unavailable/Degraded
  - Suggest retry after a short interval; if planned maintenance is in progress, indicate general timing. Preserve user-entered data for later submission.

### Error Handling Flow (Business-Level)
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Experience"
    A["User Attempts Action"] --> B["Evaluate Request State"]
    B --> C{"Is User Authenticated?"}
    C -->|"No"| D["Guide to Sign In or Verify Email"]
    C -->|"Yes"| E{"Has Permission?"}
    E -->|"No"| F["Show Not Permitted Message"]
    E -->|"Yes"| G{"Is Input Valid?"}
    G -->|"No"| H["Show Field-Specific Guidance"]
    G -->|"Yes"| I{"Resource State OK?"}
    I -->|"No"| J["Handle Not Found or Conflict"]
    I -->|"Yes"| K{"Service Healthy?"}
    K -->|"No"| L["Show Retry Guidance and Preserve Input"]
    K -->|"Yes"| M["Perform Action Successfully"]
  end
```

## Conflict Resolution for Concurrent Updates (Business Perspective)
Concurrent edits occur when the same item is open on multiple devices or sessions. Behavior protects user data and ensures clarity.

Principles:
- No silent overwrites; inform users when the item changed elsewhere.
- Provide options with safe defaults to minimize unintended data loss.
- Communicate that the item changed and the user’s pending edits may conflict.

Resolution options (business-level; not UI design):
- Review and Merge: update the draft to reflect the latest version and reapply the user’s edits.
- Overwrite with My Changes: overwrite the current item with the user’s edits.
- Discard My Edits: discard the user’s edits and accept the latest item state.

Expected behaviors:
- Pause the save operation upon detecting a conflict and present the options above.
- For Review and Merge, provide the latest version while retaining the user’s attempted changes for manual reconciliation.
- For Overwrite, apply the user’s edits and record that overwrite was chosen for audit purposes.
- For Discard My Edits, revert to the latest version and confirm completion to the user.

### Conflict Handling Flow (Business-Level)
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Submits Changes"] --> B["Detect Version Mismatch"]
  B --> C{"Conflict Detected?"}
  C -->|"No"| D["Save Changes"]
  C -->|"Yes"| E["Inform and Offer Options"]
  E --> F{"User Choice"}
  F -->|"Review and Merge"| G["Load Latest and Retain Edits"]
  F -->|"Overwrite"| H["Apply Edits and Mark Overwrite"]
  F -->|"Discard My Edits"| I["Show Latest and Discard Attempt"]
  G --> J["Complete Reconciliation and Save"]
  H --> J
  I --> K["Return to Item View"]
```

## Audit and Monitoring Expectations (Business-Level)
Audit and monitoring provide accountability, security, and service quality without exposing sensitive content.

Audit scope (business events):
- Sign-in successes and failures (no sensitive secrets retained).
- Email verification initiation and completion.
- Session terminations, including user-initiated global logout.
- Authorization denials for protected actions.
- Validation denials with categorical reasons (e.g., "title length").
- Not found attempts on protected resources.
- Conflict detections and chosen resolutions (merge, overwrite, discard).
- Rate limit denials by action category.
- Service unavailable or degraded events affecting user actions.

Monitoring scope (business indicators):
- Error rate by category and action (e.g., percentage of failed creates due to validation).
- Retry success rates after guidance.
- Time-to-recovery for transient failures.
- Distribution of conflict resolution choices.
- Rate limit incidents per user segment.

Privacy expectations:
- Exclude sensitive secrets and private todo text from audit entries; use categorical labels (e.g., "validation: title length exceeded").
- Aggregated, non-identifying analytics may be used to improve service quality.

Retention expectations:
- Maintain audit records for a period consistent with business and legal requirements. Summarized metrics may be retained longer than raw events where permissible.

## EARS-Formatted Error Requirements and Acceptance Criteria
All requirements appear in EARS format to ensure clarity and testability.

### Authentication (EARS)
- WHEN a user submits invalid credentials, THE todoApp SHALL show the message "We couldn’t sign you in. Check your email and password and try again." and guide immediate retry.
- WHEN a user attempts to sign in with an unverified email, THE todoApp SHALL present an email verification required message and allow retry after verification completes.
- WHEN a user’s session has expired, THE todoApp SHALL prompt the user to sign in again and, upon success, return to the prior action context.
- IF the same user triggers sign out from all devices, THEN THE todoApp SHALL terminate existing sessions and require re-authentication for further actions.

Acceptance criteria (Authentication):
- THE todoApp SHALL use standard, consistent phrasing for the same situations across the service.
- THE todoApp SHALL record sign-in failures as auditable, non-sensitive events suitable for monitoring.

### Authorization (EARS)
- WHEN a user attempts an action without permission, THE todoApp SHALL display "You don’t have permission to do that." and suggest a safe navigation path.
- IF a user attempts to access another user’s item, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny access without revealing the item’s existence or ownership.

Acceptance criteria (Authorization):
- THE todoApp SHALL apply a consistent tone for permission denials.
- THE todoApp SHALL categorize permission denials in audit logs for monitoring.

### Validation (EARS)
- WHEN a user attempts to create an item without a title, THE todoApp SHALL present guidance that a title is required and must be 1–120 characters.
- WHEN a user provides a description longer than 1,000 characters, THE todoApp SHALL indicate the limit and prompt the user to shorten it.
- WHEN a user provides a due date earlier than the creation date or more than 5 years in the future (user’s time zone), THE todoApp SHALL prompt for a valid due date.
- WHEN some fields are valid and others are not, THE todoApp SHALL preserve valid inputs and ask the user to correct only the invalid fields.

Acceptance criteria (Validation):
- THE todoApp SHALL present a single, concrete reason per invalid field.
- THE todoApp SHALL preserve all valid inputs during correction.

### Not Found (EARS)
- WHEN a user requests an item that does not exist or is no longer available, THE todoApp SHALL show an unavailability message and suggest returning to the user’s list or refreshing.
- IF a user follows an outdated link to an item, THEN THE todoApp SHALL suggest refreshing or navigating back to the list without revealing ownership information.

Acceptance criteria (Not Found):
- THE todoApp SHALL avoid disclosing existence or ownership of resources the user cannot access.
- THE todoApp SHALL always provide a safe navigation path.

### Conflict (EARS)
- WHEN concurrent modification is detected, THE todoApp SHALL pause the save and present the options "Review and Merge", "Overwrite", and "Discard My Edits".
- WHEN the user selects "Review and Merge", THE todoApp SHALL load the latest version and retain the user’s attempted changes for manual reconciliation.
- WHEN the user selects "Overwrite", THE todoApp SHALL apply the user’s edits and record the overwrite choice for audit purposes.
- WHEN the user selects "Discard My Edits", THE todoApp SHALL show the latest version and discard the user’s attempted changes.

Acceptance criteria (Conflict):
- THE todoApp SHALL prevent silent overwrites when a save is in conflict.
- THE todoApp SHALL make no state change unless the user chooses one of the provided resolution options.

### Rate Limit (EARS)
- WHERE a single user performs more than 60 write actions (create/update/delete) within 1 minute, THE todoApp SHALL inform the user "You’ve reached the limit for this action. Please wait a moment and try again." and allow retry after approximately 1 minute.
- WHERE sign-in attempts exceed 10 within 10 minutes for a user, THE todoApp SHALL temporarily block further attempts and present retry guidance and a password reset path.
- WHERE other sensitive actions are repeated excessively within a short time, THE todoApp SHALL provide clear guidance on usage limits and approximate wait time.

Acceptance criteria (Rate Limit):
- THE todoApp SHALL communicate an approximate remaining wait time in natural language.
- THE todoApp SHALL aggregate rate limit incidents for monitoring.

### Service Unavailable / Degraded (EARS)
- WHEN a temporary service issue prevents completing a request, THE todoApp SHALL present retry guidance and suggest waiting briefly before trying again.
- WHERE a planned maintenance window is active, THE todoApp SHALL indicate limited availability and suggest retry after maintenance ends.
- WHILE the service is partially degraded, THE todoApp SHALL name the affected feature areas and suggest alternatives if available.
- IF a request fails but user-entered data can be preserved safely, THEN THE todoApp SHALL preserve the data so the user can resubmit later.

Acceptance criteria (Service Unavailable / Degraded):
- THE todoApp SHALL notify failure without losing user-entered data and provide a retry path.
- THE todoApp SHALL support proactive messages for predictable limitations such as scheduled maintenance.

### Cross-Cutting Error Handling Principles (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL avoid exposing technical internals (e.g., internal error codes or identifiers) in user-facing messages.
- THE todoApp SHALL use consistent tone and language for the same error situations across the service.
- THE todoApp SHALL preserve the user’s recent working context where feasible so work can continue after recovery.
- THE todoApp SHALL provide a one-step retry mechanism for recoverable failures where possible.
- THE todoApp SHALL emit non-identifying audit and monitoring events for every error category.

## Acceptance Test Scenarios (EARS)
- WHEN a user submits creation without a title, THE todoApp SHALL display title validation guidance immediately and preserve other entered fields.
- WHEN a user attempts to complete an item after the session has expired, THE todoApp SHALL prompt for sign-in and, upon success, continue with the completion attempt.
- WHEN two devices save edits to the same item nearly simultaneously, THE todoApp SHALL commit one save and, for the other, show a conflict message with resolution options.
- WHEN a user exceeds 60 write attempts within a minute, THE todoApp SHALL limit additional attempts and display wait guidance.
- WHEN the service is temporarily unavailable, THE todoApp SHALL preserve user-entered input and encourage retry after a short interval.

## Glossary (Business-Level)
- Authentication: Verifying a user’s identity.
- Authorization: Determining whether a user has permission for an action.
- Validation: Checking that input values comply with business rules.
- Conflict: A situation where attempted changes differ from the current resource state.
- Rate Limit: A business-defined threshold on action frequency to protect users and the service.
- Service Degraded/Unavailable: A temporary reduction or loss of service capability.

## Traceability
- Authentication and authorization behaviors align with the [User Roles and Authentication Requirements for todoApp](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md).
- Validation and not found behaviors align with the [Functional Requirements for todoApp](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md).
- Conflict handling aligns with the [User Flows for todoApp](./05-todoApp-user-flows.md).
- Retry and service health expectations align with the [Non-Functional Requirements for todoApp](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md).
