keyQuestions: What performance is expected for core operations?
What security and privacy standards must be met?
What availability and reliability targets apply?
constraints: State measurable targets in user terms (e.g., within N seconds)
Avoid technology choices or architectural prescriptions
Use EARS for acceptance criteria
files.content:
# 08 — todoApp Non-Functional Requirements

## Document Purpose
Business-level non-functional requirements for todoApp specifying measurable expectations for performance, security, privacy, availability, reliability, scalability, compliance, and operational monitoring. Content describes WHAT outcomes must be achieved from user and business perspectives without prescribing HOW to implement them. No API specifications, database schemas, or technology choices are included.

## Related Documents
- Service objectives and KPIs: [Service Overview for todoApp](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md)
- Roles, permissions, and session behaviors: [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md)
- User-facing failure behaviors and recovery: [Error Handling and Exception Scenarios](./07-todoApp-error-handling-and-exception-scenarios.md)

## Definitions and Assumptions
- “Interactive action”: user-triggered operations with immediate feedback (e.g., viewing list, creating/updating/completing/deleting a todo item, logging in/out).
- Time references: seconds (s) or milliseconds (ms) and percentiles (p50, p95, p99) measured at the boundary where the user perceives completion.
- “Business day”: 09:00–18:00 in Asia/Seoul (KST) unless stated otherwise. Scheduled maintenance references local time in KST.
- “Sensitive action”: operations that affect account control or privacy (e.g., password change, email change, account deletion, session revocation).
- “Peak period”: high-usage windows typical of 19:00–23:00 KST on weekdays and 10:00–23:00 KST on weekends.
- Confidential and personal data: identifiers (e.g., email), authentication factors, and any user-generated content in todo items or metadata.

---

## Performance and Responsiveness Expectations
Targets are user-perceived. Unless otherwise noted, targets apply to the 95th percentile and must be met under the scale and concurrency assumptions defined in this document.

### Core Interaction Targets
- List own todos (paginated up to 50 items): p95 ≤ 300 ms; p99 ≤ 600 ms.
- Create a todo: p95 ≤ 400 ms; p99 ≤ 800 ms.
- Update a todo (title/description/due date): p95 ≤ 400 ms; p99 ≤ 800 ms.
- Complete or reopen a todo: p95 ≤ 300 ms; p99 ≤ 600 ms.
- Delete a todo: p95 ≤ 400 ms; p99 ≤ 800 ms.
- Bulk complete/reopen up to 50 items: p95 ≤ 1,000 ms; p99 ≤ 2,000 ms.
- Authentication (enter credentials to signed-in state): p95 ≤ 2,000 ms; p99 ≤ 4,000 ms.
- Email-based actions (verification or password reset): email dispatched within 60 s p95.
- Admin lookups for a single user account (non-invasive read): p95 ≤ 800 ms.

### Payload and Result Size Expectations
- Interactive list retrieval pagination: up to 50 items per request; results include only fields necessary for list view.
- Todo description length supported up to 1,000 characters without truncation in storage; interactive viewing and editing meet targets above for up to 1,000 characters.
- Import/export operations that exceed interactive targets SHALL be processed asynchronously with progress or completion notification.

### Throughput and Concurrency Targets (Business-Level)
- MVP load: sustain 100 requests per second (RPS) aggregate with short bursts up to 300 RPS for 5 minutes without violating p95 targets.
- Concurrency: support at least 1,000 concurrently active signed-in sessions during peak periods with no degradation beyond p95 targets.
- Growth headroom: maintain stable performance up to 3× MVP sustained load without user-visible regressions greater than 20% of stated targets.

### Rate Limiting (User-Centric)
- Write operations (create/update/complete/delete) per account: up to 60 actions per minute without throttling; above this threshold may be rate-limited to protect availability.
- Read operations (list/search/filter) per account: up to 120 actions per minute without throttling; above this threshold may be rate-limited.
- Authentication attempts: protections and lockout expectations appear in Security and Privacy.

### Time Zone and Consistency
- Read-after-write for a user’s own content: subsequent reads reflect changes immediately p95 ≤ 1,000 ms and p99 ≤ 2,000 ms.
- Cross-device visibility for a user’s own changes: p95 ≤ 3,000 ms.

---

## Security and Privacy Principles
Business-aligned controls for confidentiality, integrity, and proper access, consistent with role definitions and session behaviors in the [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-todoApp-user-roles-and-authentication.md).

### Authentication and Session Management
- Only verified accounts may perform non-public actions; unverified accounts have strictly limited capabilities per roles policy.
- Sessions expire after 30 days of inactivity; sensitive actions require recent re-authentication (within the last 15 minutes).
- Users can revoke all active sessions immediately from an account security control.

### Credential and Account Protection
- Password policy: minimum 12 characters; acceptance of long passphrases; require at least three of the following: uppercase, lowercase, numbers, special characters; reject top 10,000 common passwords; prevent reuse of the previous 5 passwords.
- Login protection: after 10 failed attempts within 10 minutes for an account or from a single source, impose a cooling period of 5 minutes with user-facing guidance for secure recovery.
- Sensitive changes (email/password) require confirmation through a second-factor channel (e.g., a one-time confirmation code via the verified email channel) without prescribing specific technologies.

### Authorization and Least Privilege
- Users may only access their own content. Admin actions are logged and limited to the minimum necessary for support and policy enforcement.
- Administrative access is governed by justification and auditability; access beyond minimum necessary is prohibited.

### Data Minimization and Purpose Limitation
- Collect only data necessary to operate todoApp and provide the service.
- Prohibit storage of special categories of personal data in system-managed fields (e.g., national ID numbers) and discourage sensitive content in todo text through policy and guidance.

### Data Protection
- Protect personal data in transit and at rest using strong, industry-accepted safeguards without specifying particular ciphers or libraries.
- Protect encryption keys and secrets via processes that enforce least privilege, dual control for changes, and auditability.

### Audit Logging and Access Transparency
- Log security-relevant events: authentication successes/failures, password changes, email changes, session revocations, account deletions, admin support actions, and mass/bulk operations affecting more than 20 items.
- Provide user-accessible activity history for their own account, retaining at least 90 days of entries.

### Privacy Controls and User Rights
- Provide accessible Privacy Policy and Terms of Service before account creation and within account settings.
- Provide self-service account deletion with clear warnings about irreversible effects and data retention timelines.
- Provide export of user-owned data in a commonly used, machine-readable format within reasonable size limits.

---

## Availability and Reliability Expectations
Uptime, recovery, and continuity behaviors visible to users and administrators.

### Availability Targets
- Service-level objective (SLO) for user-facing availability: 99.9% monthly.
- Planned maintenance windows: default window Sundays 02:00–04:00 KST, announced at least 72 hours in advance. Emergency maintenance is allowed with immediate notice and clear user messaging.

### Reliability and Continuity
- RTO (Recovery Time Objective): critical user operations recover within 60 minutes following an outage.
- RPO (Recovery Point Objective): no more than 5 minutes of data for committed operations is lost in a disaster scenario.
- Durability expectation: once a user receives a success confirmation for a write, that data persists and remains retrievable after any transient fault.

### Degradation and Failover Behavior
- Graceful degradation: non-critical features (e.g., bulk operations, optional analytics) may be temporarily disabled to preserve core CRUD functionality.
- Read-only mode: during partial outages, the system may enter read-only mode with clear user messaging; write attempts are queued or safely rejected with recovery guidance per the error handling document.

### Consistency and Ordering
- For a single user’s data, operations that depend on ordering (e.g., marking complete, then deleting) reflect the most recent committed action in subsequent reads.
- Conflict handling during concurrent updates follows the business rules in the related documents, ensuring users receive clear guidance without exposing technical details.

---

## Scalability Expectations
Predictable behavior as usage grows.

### Baseline and Growth Assumptions
- MVP baseline: 50,000 monthly active users (MAU), 5,000 daily active users (DAU), 1,000 peak concurrent sessions, 100 sustained RPS with 300 RPS bursts.
- Growth: maintain targets up to 3× baseline without user-visible regressions beyond 20% of stated p95 targets and without service downtime for capacity increases.

### Business Limits
- Maximum todos per user: 10,000 total items across states. Align active-item guidance and caps with the [Business Rules and Constraints](./06-todoApp-business-rules.md) where an active cap of 5,000 may apply.
- Bulk operations: up to 100 items per interactive bulk action; larger sets are processed asynchronously with user notification upon completion.

### Elasticity and Resource Management
- Capacity increases and decreases are transparent to users and must not cause outages or data loss.

---

## Compliance and Legal Considerations
Aligned with common privacy frameworks without asserting jurisdiction-specific legal advice.

- Privacy by design: default to the minimum data necessary; privacy-related defaults are the most protective reasonable option.
- Notice and consent: obtain user consent for optional data uses such as marketing communications; provide easy opt-out.
- Data subject rights: enable access, rectification, export, and deletion of user data within 30 days of verified request.
- Child safety: intended for users aged 13+ unless local law imposes a higher age; when required, obtain guardian consent consistent with applicable law.
- Data retention: business records (e.g., audit logs) retained for 90 days minimum; user data retention after account deletion follows policy in the data lifecycle document.
- Cross-border data transfer: disclose data processing locations and ensure transfers comply with applicable cross-border requirements.

---

## Operational Monitoring and Alerting (Business Expectations)
Continuous verification that objectives are met and regressions detected promptly.

### Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
- Latency: p50/p95/p99 across core interactions (list, create, update, complete, delete, login).
- Error rate: percentage of failed interactions per category (authentication, authorization, validation, conflict, not found, service unavailable) as defined in the error handling document.
- Throughput: sustained and peak RPS; concurrency of active sessions.
- Availability: monthly uptime against the 99.9% SLO and error budget consumption.
- Security signals: failed login spikes, password reset spikes, session revocations, admin privileged operations.
- Data integrity: periodic checks that ensure committed writes are retrievable and uncorrupted.

### Alerting Thresholds and Response Expectations
- Critical user operation latency breach: if p95 for list/create/update/complete/delete exceeds target by 25% for 5 consecutive minutes, generate a critical alert.
- Availability breach: if rolling 5-minute availability falls below 99%, generate a critical alert.
- Error spike: if failed interactions exceed 2% over 10 minutes for any core operation, generate a high-severity alert with categorization.
- Security anomaly: if there are more than 50 failed logins for a single account or 500 across the service within 10 minutes, generate a high-severity alert and apply protective measures consistent with lockout policy.
- On-call responsiveness: acknowledge critical alerts within 5 minutes 24/7; initiate mitigation within 15 minutes; communicate user-facing status within 30 minutes of incident start.

### Incident Management Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Detection"
    A["Monitoring Detects Breach"] --> B["Alert Generated"]
  end
  subgraph "Triage"
    C["On-call Acknowledges"] --> D["Severity Classification"]
    D --> E["User Impact Assessment"]
  end
  subgraph "Mitigation"
    F["Apply Safeguards(Degrade/Throttle/Read-only)"] --> G["Restore Core Functions"]
  end
  subgraph "Communication"
    H["Post Status Update(KST Time)"] --> I["Customer Support Briefing"]
  end
  subgraph "Recovery"
    J["Validate Data Integrity"] --> K["Confirm SLO Recovery"]
  end
  subgraph "Postmortem"
    L["Root Cause Analysis"] --> M["Action Items&Owners"]
  end
  B --> C
  E --> F
  G --> H
  H -.-> I
  G --> J
  K --> L
```

---

## Non-Functional Acceptance Criteria (EARS)
EARS keywords WHEN/WHILE/IF/THEN/WHERE/THE/SHALL remain in English; descriptions are in business terms.

### Performance
- WHEN a user retrieves a page of their todo list up to 50 items during peak period, THE todoApp SHALL deliver the response within 300 ms at p95 and within 600 ms at p99.
- WHEN a user creates a todo with title and optional description up to 1,000 characters, THE todoApp SHALL confirm creation within 400 ms at p95 and within 800 ms at p99.
- WHEN a user completes or reopens a todo, THE todoApp SHALL reflect the change within 300 ms at p95 and within 600 ms at p99.
- WHEN a user logs in with valid credentials, THE todoApp SHALL transition to a signed-in state within 2,000 ms at p95 and within 4,000 ms at p99.
- WHERE a bulk action affects up to 50 items, THE todoApp SHALL complete the action within 1,000 ms at p95 and within 2,000 ms at p99.
- WHERE an operation exceeds interactive thresholds due to size or complexity, THE todoApp SHALL process it asynchronously and notify the user upon completion.

### Consistency and Cross-Device
- WHEN a user modifies their own todo items, THE todoApp SHALL provide read-after-write consistency for that user with visibility of the change within 1,000 ms at p95 and 2,000 ms at p99.
- WHILE a user is signed in on multiple devices, THE todoApp SHALL propagate the user’s own changes across devices within 3,000 ms at p95.

### Rate Limiting and Protection
- WHERE an account issues more than 60 write actions in 1 minute, THE todoApp SHALL apply fair-use throttling and communicate retry guidance without blocking critical security actions.
- WHERE an account issues more than 120 read actions in 1 minute, THE todoApp SHALL apply fair-use throttling and communicate retry guidance.

### Security and Sessions
- THE todoApp SHALL require account verification before granting non-public capabilities.
- WHERE a session has been inactive for 30 days, THE todoApp SHALL require re-authentication before any further non-public actions.
- IF there are 10 failed login attempts within 10 minutes for an account, THEN THE todoApp SHALL impose a 5-minute cooldown and provide secure recovery guidance to the user.
- IF a user invokes “revoke all sessions”, THEN THE todoApp SHALL invalidate all existing sessions within 60 seconds and require re-authentication on all devices.
- WHERE a user initiates a sensitive action, THE todoApp SHALL require recent re-authentication within the last 15 minutes.
- THE todoApp SHALL enforce a password policy with minimum 12 characters and at least three character classes; banned password list and recent-password reuse prevention apply.

### Data Protection and Privacy
- THE todoApp SHALL protect personal data in transit and at rest using strong safeguards and prevent unauthorized access by design and policy.
- WHERE audit logs contain personal data, THE todoApp SHALL minimize and redact sensitive fields and retain logs for at least 90 days.
- WHEN a verified user requests export of their data up to 1 GB in size, THE todoApp SHALL provide a machine-readable export within 24 hours under normal operating conditions.
- WHERE a verified user’s export exceeds typical size, THE todoApp SHALL communicate progress and deliver the export as soon as preparation completes.
- WHEN a verified user requests account deletion, THE todoApp SHALL remove user-accessible content promptly and complete deletion workflows within 30 days except where legal retention is required.

### Availability and Reliability
- THE todoApp SHALL achieve 99.9% monthly availability for core user operations under the defined load assumptions.
- WHEN a service incident impacts users, THE todoApp SHALL publish a status update within 30 minutes of detection and provide subsequent updates at least every 60 minutes until resolution.
- WHERE core functionality is impaired, THE todoApp SHALL prioritize read access and safe queuing or rejection of writes with clear guidance.
- WHEN service is restored after an outage, THE todoApp SHALL meet the stated p95 performance targets within 15 minutes of recovery.
- THE todoApp SHALL meet an RTO of 60 minutes and an RPO of 5 minutes for committed user operations.

### Monitoring and Alerts
- WHEN p95 latency for any core operation exceeds its target by 25% for 5 consecutive minutes, THE todoApp SHALL generate a critical alert for the on-call responder.
- WHEN failed user interactions exceed 2% of attempts over a 10-minute window for any core operation, THE todoApp SHALL generate a high-severity alert with categorization.
- WHEN security anomalies occur (e.g., more than 50 failed logins for an account or 500 service-wide within 10 minutes), THE todoApp SHALL generate a high-severity alert and apply protective measures.
- WHERE a critical alert is generated, THE todoApp SHALL ensure on-call acknowledgment within 5 minutes and user-facing communication within 30 minutes.

### Compliance and Legal
- THE todoApp SHALL present accessible Terms of Service and Privacy Policy before account creation and within settings.
- WHEN receiving a verified data subject request, THE todoApp SHALL fulfill access, rectification, export, or deletion within 30 days.
- WHERE local law requires consent for optional data uses, THE todoApp SHALL capture, honor, and provide revocation of such consent.

---

## Appendices

### A. p95/p99 Target Summary

| Category | p95 | p99 |
|---|---:|---:|
| List todos (≤50 items) | 300 ms | 600 ms |
| Create todo | 400 ms | 800 ms |
| Update todo | 400 ms | 800 ms |
| Complete/Reopen todo | 300 ms | 600 ms |
| Bulk action (≤50 items) | 1,000 ms | 2,000 ms |
| Login (valid credentials) | 2,000 ms | 4,000 ms |

### B. Additional Non-Functional Targets

| Target | Value |
|---|---|
| Email dispatch (verification/reset) | ≤ 60 s at p95 |
| Availability (monthly) | 99.9% |
| RTO | 60 minutes |
| RPO | 5 minutes |
| Session inactivity expiry | 30 days |
| Sensitive action re-auth window | 15 minutes |
| Audit log retention | ≥ 90 days |
| Export SLA (≤1 GB) | ≤ 24 hours under normal conditions |

---

Business-requirements-only scope applies. All technical implementation decisions, including architecture, APIs, and data design, belong to the development team. The content defines outcomes and constraints to be met from user and business perspectives.

outline: Data Creation, Update, and Deletion Lifecycle
Right to Erasure and Account Deletion Behaviors
Traceability to Business Rules and Non-Functional Requirements
keyQuestions: How is user data handled from creation to deletion?
What privacy safeguards are required across the lifecycle?

files.content:
# todoApp Data Lifecycle and Privacy Requirements

Business requirements only; all technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, and storage technologies) belong to the development team. The content defines WHAT todoApp must do for data across its lifecycle, not HOW to implement it.

## 1. Conceptual Data Flow Overview (business‑level)

Data categories
- User Account Data: identity and authentication attributes needed to operate an account, plus preferences strictly necessary to provide the service.
- Todo Item Data: user‑owned task records with required fields (e.g., title, status) and optional fields (e.g., description, due date) per functional scope.
- Operational Security Data: verification/reset artifacts, sessions, and related metadata necessary for authentication and authorization.
- Administrative and Audit Data: minimal event logs and administrative actions required for support, safety, fraud control, and compliance oversight.
- Aggregated Analytics (Non‑Personal): metrics computed so that they cannot be used to re‑identify individuals.

Conceptual flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Initiated"
    A["Account Creation"] --> B["Email Verification"]
    B --> C["User Login"]
    C --> D["Create/Update Todo Items"]
    D --> E["Complete/Reopen/Delete Todo Items"]
    C --> I["Request Export"]
  end

  subgraph "System Governance"
    F["Retention Counters"] --> G["Soft Delete Window"]
    G --> H["Scheduled Purge"]
    J["Prepare User Data Export"] --> K["Deliver Export Package"]
    L["Audit Events"] --> M["Time‑bound Retention"]
    N["Backups/Snapshots"] --> O["Expiry per Policy"]
  end

  A --> P["Account Profile"]
  D --> Q["Todo Dataset"]
  E --> Q
  C --> R["Session Lifecycle"]
  I --> J
  H --> S["Permanent Deletion"]
  M --> T["Expiry or Legal Hold"]
  Q -.-> U["Indexes/Caches(Update)"]
```

Notes
- "Soft Delete Window" is a reversible state prior to permanent deletion.
- "Scheduled Purge" removes data permanently when retention conditions are met.
- "Backups/Snapshots" are immutable recovery copies; access is restricted to disaster recovery scenarios and expire per policy.

## 2. Data Creation, Read, Update, Completion/Reopen, and Deletion Lifecycle

### 2.1 Ownership and Access
- Users (role: user) own and control their account data and todo items.
- Administrators (role: admin) operate under least‑privilege for support, safety, and policy enforcement. Administrative access to user data is limited to specific, auditable actions justified by a legitimate business need.

### 2.2 Creation Requirements (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL record the creator’s user identifier as the immutable owner of each todo item at creation time.
- WHEN a user creates a todo item, THE todoApp SHALL store only fields defined as necessary by the functional scope and business rules.
- IF a creation request omits a required business field, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the creation with a clear explanation referencing the missing or invalid field.
- WHERE optional fields are provided at creation, THE todoApp SHALL validate them against business rules before accepting the item.

### 2.3 Read and Listing Requirements (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL allow a user to view only their own todo items and account data, except where an admin performs a permitted support action under audit.
- WHEN a user lists todo items, THE todoApp SHALL return only items not permanently deleted and within the user’s ownership scope.
- WHERE filters and sorting are requested, THE todoApp SHALL apply only supported business‑level filters and sorts as defined in the functional requirements.

### 2.4 Update Requirements (EARS)
- WHEN a user updates a todo item they own, THE todoApp SHALL validate each changed field against business rules and persist only if all validations pass.
- IF an update conflicts with a more recent change, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent silent overwrites and provide guidance for conflict resolution.
- THE todoApp SHALL record the time and actor for each successful update in an auditable manner without exposing implementation details to end users.

### 2.5 Completion/Reopen Requirements (EARS)
- WHEN a user marks an item as completed, THE todoApp SHALL set the item’s status to completed and record the completion timestamp.
- WHEN a user reopens a completed item, THE todoApp SHALL revert the status and clear or update completion metadata as defined by business rules.

### 2.6 Deletion Requirements (EARS)
- WHEN a user deletes a todo item, THE todoApp SHALL move the item to a soft‑delete state that hides it from normal listings and starts a retention countdown.
- WHILE a todo item is in soft‑delete, THE todoApp SHALL allow the owner to restore it within the defined retention window.
- IF the soft‑delete retention window elapses, THEN THE todoApp SHALL permanently delete the item during the next scheduled purge.
- WHERE an admin flags content for policy violations, THE todoApp SHALL allow immediate soft‑delete with admin justification recorded in audit data.

## 3. Retention and Purging Policies

Retention is purpose‑driven and time‑bound. Policy durations are business requirements and may be changed only through documented policy updates.

### 3.1 Todo Items (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL retain active todo items indefinitely until the owner deletes them or the account is deleted.
- WHEN a todo item is soft‑deleted by its owner, THE todoApp SHALL retain it for up to 30 days to allow restoration.
- IF a soft‑deleted todo item reaches 30 days without restoration, THEN THE todoApp SHALL permanently delete it during the next scheduled purge.

### 3.2 Accounts and Profiles (EARS)
- WHEN an account is created but not verified within 14 days, THE todoApp SHALL purge the unverified account and associated artifacts.
- WHEN a verified user requests account deletion, THE todoApp SHALL initiate a 14‑day grace period before permanent deletion to allow reversal.
- IF the grace period elapses without reversal, THEN THE todoApp SHALL permanently delete the account and all user‑owned todo items during the next scheduled purge.

### 3.3 Operational Security Data (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL limit the lifetime of one‑time email verification artifacts to 24 hours from issuance.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit the lifetime of password reset artifacts to 1 hour from issuance.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit the lifetime of user sessions according to the authentication policy defined in the roles and authentication requirements.

### 3.4 Administrative and Audit Data (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL retain minimal audit events necessary to reconstruct security‑ and policy‑relevant actions for 180 days unless a longer retention is mandated by documented legal obligations.
- WHERE a legal hold is in effect, THE todoApp SHALL suspend purge of affected audit records until the hold is lifted.

### 3.5 Aggregated Analytics (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL keep only aggregated, non‑personal metrics that cannot feasibly be re‑identified.
- WHERE any analytics processing would require personal data, THE todoApp SHALL either minimize and anonymize the input or forego the processing to protect user privacy.

### 3.6 Purge Execution (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL execute purge processes on a predictable schedule (at least daily) to remove data whose retention windows have expired.
- IF a purge process fails partially, THEN THE todoApp SHALL retry purging the remaining eligible records without duplicating prior deletions.

### 3.7 Backups and Disaster Recovery Copies (Business‑Level)
- THE todoApp SHALL maintain immutable backup/snapshot copies only for disaster recovery and service continuity.
- WHERE user data is deleted from active systems, THE todoApp SHALL ensure that any residual presence in immutable backups is inaccessible for normal operations and expires automatically per backup retention policy.
- IF a disaster recovery event requires restoration from backups, THEN THE todoApp SHALL re‑apply applicable deletion and retention rules to restored data as soon as operationally feasible.

## 4. User‑Controlled Export/Portability (optional)

### 4.1 Scope
User export includes user‑owned account data and todo item content within the user’s ownership scope. Audit logs, administrative justifications, and internal security artifacts are excluded from user export unless required by applicable law.

### 4.2 Export Requirements (EARS)
- WHEN a user requests an export, THE todoApp SHALL prepare a complete, machine‑readable package of the user’s account data and todo items.
- THE todoApp SHALL deliver the export within 24 hours of the request under normal operating conditions.
- WHERE an export is large or complex, THE todoApp SHALL communicate progress and provide the completed package once preparation is finished.
- THE todoApp SHALL limit export requests to once per rolling 7‑day period per user to manage capacity and abuse risk.
- WHERE identity verification is required, THE todoApp SHALL complete appropriate verification before releasing an export package.

## 5. Privacy‑by‑Design Principles

### 5.1 Foundational Principles (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL default to the most privacy‑preserving state for all new features and data flows (privacy by default).
- THE todoApp SHALL enforce least privilege for all role‑based access to user data.
- THE todoApp SHALL ensure purpose limitation by collecting and processing data only for clearly defined, legitimate purposes necessary to operate todoApp.
- THE todoApp SHALL ensure transparency by documenting data uses and changes to policy in a user‑accessible location.

### 5.2 Administrative Access Governance (EARS)
- WHERE an admin must access user data for support or policy enforcement, THE todoApp SHALL require an explicit business justification recorded in audit data.
- IF an admin action impacts a user’s data materially (e.g., forced deletion for policy), THEN THE todoApp SHALL record the action with actor, time, scope, and justification in audit data.

### 5.3 Security Posture at Business Level (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL protect personal data at rest and in transit using industry‑appropriate safeguards without prescribing specific technologies.
- THE todoApp SHALL restrict access to personal data to authorized roles only, consistent with the defined permission model.

### 5.4 Review Gates for New Data Uses (EARS)
- WHERE a new data category or use is proposed, THE todoApp SHALL undergo a privacy review to confirm minimization, purpose limitation, and retention alignment before launch.
- IF a proposed use cannot meet privacy principles, THEN THE todoApp SHALL block the change until a compliant approach is defined.

## 6. Data Minimization and Purpose Limitation

### 6.1 Data Collection Boundaries (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL collect only the minimum personal data required to operate user accounts and manage todo items (e.g., contact identifier and authentication secrets).
- WHERE optional data is provided by the user (e.g., description, due date), THE todoApp SHALL use it solely to enhance the todo management experience.
- THE todoApp SHALL avoid collecting special categories of personal data; if such data is inadvertently submitted in free‑text fields, THE todoApp SHALL treat it with heightened protection and refrain from using it for profiling or analytics.

### 6.2 Data Use Boundaries (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL not sell personal data or share it with third parties for independent marketing purposes.
- WHERE service providers are engaged to operate core functionality, THE todoApp SHALL ensure they process data only on behalf of todoApp for permitted purposes.

### 6.3 Storage Boundaries (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL not store personal data beyond the retention periods defined in this document unless required by legal obligations documented by policy.

## 7. Right to Erasure and Account Deletion Behaviors

### 7.1 Conceptual Deletion Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Action"
    A["User Requests Account Deletion"] --> B["Start 14‑day Grace Period"]
    B --> C{"Login During Grace?"}
  end

  subgraph "System Outcomes"
    D["Cancel Deletion and Restore Access"]
    E["Maintain Grace and Restricted Access"]
    F["Permanent Deletion at Purge"]
  end

  C -->|"Yes"| D
  C -->|"No"| E
  E --> G{"Grace Expired?"}
  G -->|"Yes"| F
  G -->|"No"| E
```

### 7.2 Erasure Requirements (EARS)
- WHEN a verified user requests account deletion, THE todoApp SHALL initiate a 14‑day grace period and notify the user of the effective deletion date.
- WHILE an account is in the grace period, THE todoApp SHALL restrict access to read‑only export and deletion cancellation; normal write operations SHALL be blocked.
- IF the user logs in and cancels during the grace period, THEN THE todoApp SHALL restore full access and stop the deletion process immediately.
- IF the grace period ends without cancellation, THEN THE todoApp SHALL permanently delete the account, user‑owned todo items, and user‑specific preferences during the next scheduled purge.
- WHERE deletion would impact records under legal hold or unresolved disputes, THE todoApp SHALL defer deletion of those specific records while completing deletion of all other user data.

### 7.3 Exceptions and Residual Data (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL preserve non‑identifying, aggregated analytics after account deletion, provided such aggregates cannot be used to re‑identify the user.
- WHERE audit records must be retained for security or compliance, THE todoApp SHALL retain only the minimum necessary audit data for the mandated period, decoupled from content details where feasible.
- WHERE immutable backups exist, THE todoApp SHALL allow residual traces to expire per backup policy and SHALL not restore deleted user data for ordinary requests.

## 8. Additional Lifecycle Topics

### 8.1 Data Lineage and Auditability (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL maintain auditable records for materially significant events: account lifecycle, session lifecycle, item creation/update/deletion, admin access with justification, export requests and deliveries, purge executions, and legal hold changes.
- WHERE feasible, THE todoApp SHALL include actor, timestamp (UTC), target scope, and outcome in audit entries while avoiding sensitive content.
- IF an audit entry would expose secrets or personal content, THEN THE todoApp SHALL store categorical labels instead of raw content.

### 8.2 Caching and Indexing Propagation (EARS)
- WHEN todo items change state (create/update/complete/reopen/delete), THE todoApp SHALL propagate visibility changes to derived representations (e.g., caches, indexes) within a user‑perceived short interval aligned with non‑functional targets.
- IF an index or cache temporarily presents stale results, THEN THE todoApp SHALL converge to the correct state within the non‑functional consistency window and avoid re‑exposing permanently deleted content.

### 8.3 Non‑Production/Test Data Controls (EARS)
- THE todoApp SHALL prohibit the use of live personal data in non‑production environments unless de‑identified to a level that prevents re‑identification.
- WHERE test data is needed, THE todoApp SHALL use synthetic or de‑identified datasets and SHALL destroy them when no longer needed.

### 8.4 Third‑Party Processors and Data Transfers (EARS)
- WHERE subprocessors are used to provide core capabilities (e.g., email delivery), THE todoApp SHALL ensure they act as processors on behalf of todoApp and process only for permitted purposes.
- WHERE cross‑border transfer is required to operate the service, THE todoApp SHALL disclose the general regions involved and ensure transfers occur under appropriate safeguards consistent with applicable policy.

### 8.5 Consent and Preference Management (EARS)
- WHERE optional communications or features require consent, THE todoApp SHALL capture, honor, and allow revocation of consent without degrading core functionality.
- IF a user revokes consent, THEN THE todoApp SHALL cease the associated processing promptly and update preference records accordingly.

### 8.6 Data Subject Requests Beyond Deletion (EARS)
- WHEN a verified user requests access to their personal data, THE todoApp SHALL provide a summary of user‑owned data and profile attributes in a human‑readable and machine‑readable form within a reasonable timeframe communicated to the user (target within 30 days unless policy dictates faster timelines).
- WHEN a verified user requests rectification of inaccurate personal data they control (e.g., display name), THE todoApp SHALL allow correction and reflect changes in derived views and caches within the non‑functional consistency window.
- WHERE a request is manifestly unfounded or excessive under applicable policy, THE todoApp SHALL provide a business‑level explanation and may decline the request consistent with policy.

### 8.7 Data Breach Response Expectations (Business‑Level)
- WHEN a data incident is suspected to have impacted personal data, THE todoApp SHALL initiate incident response procedures, assess scope and impact, and provide user‑facing communication consistent with applicable policy and timelines.
- WHERE notification is required, THE todoApp SHALL communicate in clear, user‑centric language describing what happened, what data may be involved, protective steps users can take, and how todoApp is addressing the issue.

## 9. Traceability to Business Rules and Non‑Functional Requirements

- Refer to the [Business Rules and Validation Guide](./06-todoApp-business-rules.md) for field‑level validations, ownership, trash/restore rules, rate limits, and time‑zone handling that complement lifecycle behaviors.
- Refer to the [Non‑Functional Requirements and Service Expectations](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md) for performance, availability, security, and operational monitoring expectations that constrain lifecycle operations.

Traceability highlights
- Creation, update, and deletion validations: Business Rules → Todo Item Validation Rules and Ownership.
- Export responsiveness and delivery window: Non‑Functional → Performance targets for asynchronous operations.
- Audit and monitoring expectations: Non‑Functional → Operational Monitoring and Alerting.

## 10. Business‑Level Acceptance and Monitoring Criteria (EARS)

- THE todoApp SHALL complete visible create, update, and delete operations on user data within 2 seconds under normal operating conditions.
- THE todoApp SHALL execute daily purge cycles that remove all data past retention within 24 hours of eligibility.
- WHEN a user requests export, THE todoApp SHALL provide the export within 24 hours under normal operating conditions.
- WHEN a user initiates account deletion, THE todoApp SHALL enforce the 14‑day grace period and execute permanent deletion at the next scheduled purge thereafter.
- WHERE legal hold or compliance exceptions apply, THE todoApp SHALL document the scope and duration and prevent deletion of the held records until the hold is removed.
- WHERE backups contain residual copies, THE todoApp SHALL ensure they are inaccessible for ordinary operations and expire automatically per policy.
- WHEN a user requests access or rectification, THE todoApp SHALL fulfill the request within a reasonable timeframe communicated to the user (target within 30 days unless policy dictates otherwise).

## 11. Error and Recovery Expectations Across the Lifecycle (EARS)

- IF a user attempts to restore a todo item after the retention window has expired, THEN THE todoApp SHALL inform the user that restoration is no longer possible and the item has been permanently deleted.
- IF an export preparation exceeds the standard 24‑hour window due to exceptional load, THEN THE todoApp SHALL notify the user of delay and deliver the export as soon as preparation completes.
- IF a purge process encounters inconsistencies, THEN THE todoApp SHALL isolate affected records, log the issue for investigation, and continue purging unaffected eligible records.
- IF an admin‑initiated action is missing a documented justification, THEN THE todoApp SHALL block the action and request a valid justification entry.
- IF derived indexes or caches temporarily lag after deletion, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent re‑exposure of deleted content and converge to the correct state within the non‑functional consistency window.

## 12. Data Categorization (Business‑Level)

| Category | Examples | Owner | Primary Uses | Retention (Business Policy) | Purge Path |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| User Account Data | Email, display name, locale/time zone, verification status | User | Authentication, personalization | Unverified: 14 days; Verified: until deletion request + 14‑day grace | Account deletion purge |
| Todo Item Data | Title, description, due date, status, timestamps | User | Personal task management | Active: indefinite; Soft‑deleted: 30 days | Soft‑delete → scheduled purge |
| Operational Security Data | Verification tokens, reset tokens, session metadata | System | Authentication and recovery | Verification: 24h; Reset: 1h; Sessions: per auth policy | Expire on schedule |
| Administrative and Audit Data | Admin actions, access justifications, security‑relevant events | System | Accountability, safety, compliance | 180 days or per legal hold | Scheduled purge or hold release |
| Aggregated Analytics | De‑identified usage metrics | System | Service improvement | As needed, non‑reidentifiable | Not applicable (non‑personal) |
| Backups/Snapshots | Immutable copies for DR only | System | Disaster recovery | Per backup policy (time‑bound) | Automatic expiry; re‑apply deletions post‑restore |

## 13. Additional Visuals

### 13.1 Todo Item Soft‑Delete Lifecycle
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Active Item"] --> B["User Deletes(Item→Soft‑Delete)"]
  B --> C{"Within 30 Days?"}
  C -->|"Yes"| D["User Restores(Item→Active)"]
  C -->|"No"| E["Scheduled Purge(Permanent Deletion)"]
```

### 13.2 Export Request Flow (Business‑Level)
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["User Requests Export"] --> B["Verify Identity"]
  B --> C{"Verified?"}
  C -->|"Yes"| D["Prepare Package(Machine‑Readable)"]
  C -->|"No"| E["Request Verification"]
  D --> F{"Large/Complex?"}
  F -->|"Yes"| G["Communicate Progress"]
  F -->|"No"| H["Deliver Export"]
  G --> H
```

## 14. Glossary (Business‑Level)

- Aggregated Analytics: Non‑personal statistical measures that cannot be traced back to an identifiable individual.
- Audit Event: A recorded business event capturing actor, time, scope, and outcome without sensitive content.
- Grace Period: A bounded time during which a user may reverse a pending account deletion.
- Legal Hold: A suspension of purge and deletion for specific records due to legal or compliance obligations.
- Personal Data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person within todoApp’s scope (e.g., email, user‑generated todo content).
- Pseudonymization: Processing data in a manner that it can no longer be attributed to a specific user without additional information kept separately.
- Soft Delete: A reversible state in which data is hidden from normal operations and scheduled for purge after a retention window.
- Permanent Deletion (Hard Delete): Irreversible removal of data from active systems following retention rules.
- Subprocessor: A service provider engaged to process personal data on behalf of todoApp for permitted purposes.

---

Business requirements only; developers have full autonomy to determine the technical architecture, interfaces, storage strategies, and operational mechanisms necessary to satisfy these requirements while adhering to organizational standards and applicable laws.

files.content:
# todoApp – Acceptance Criteria and Success Metrics

Document date: 2025-08-15 (Asia/Seoul)

Business requirements only; all technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, libraries, infrastructure) are at the discretion of the development team. Content defines WHAT must be satisfied for go‑live and post‑launch success in business terms, not HOW to build it.

## Related Reading
- Vision, scope, and model context: [todoApp Service Overview](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md)
- Feature scope and behaviors: [todoApp Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md)
- Quality targets and constraints: [todoApp Non‑Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md)

## 1) Release Readiness Checklist
All items must be satisfied before declaring the MVP “Go‑Live Ready.” Items are business‑measurable and auditable.

1. Scope and Feature Completeness
   - MVP feature set matches the [todoApp Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md): account registration/login/logout, email verification, password reset/change, session revocation, todo item create/read/update/delete, completion/reopen, optional description and due date, filtering/sorting, timezone handling, data ownership/privacy rules, and optional export.
   - No open P0/P1 defects affecting core flows: register, verify, login, view list, create todo, edit, complete/reopen, delete, filter/sort.
   - All acceptance tests in Section 2 pass with documented evidence and traceability to requirements.
   - Known limitations are documented with mitigation or deferral notes; no hidden scope gaps remain for MVP.

2. Non‑Functional Readiness
   - Performance sampling under representative load meets p95 ≤ 2 seconds user‑perceived for core actions (register, login, list, add, edit, complete, delete, filter/sort) and aligns with the [todoApp Non‑Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md).
   - Availability plan, on‑call schedule, and escalation matrix prepared for the first 4 weeks; coverage confirmed for the first 72 hours post‑launch.
   - Monitoring dashboards for KPIs and error categories configured and accessible to stakeholders; alert thresholds tested.
   - Read‑after‑write and cross‑device visibility behaviors validated against non‑functional targets.

3. Security, Privacy, and Compliance Readiness
   - Password, rate‑limit, and session policies validated as per [Roles and Authentication] and NFR expectations.
   - Privacy notices, Terms of Service, and data lifecycle policies published and consistent with [todoApp Data Lifecycle and Privacy Requirements] if applicable.
   - Audit trail coverage validated for significant account events and todo changes; sampling demonstrates integrity and minimal sensitive exposure.
   - Access control checks validated for user/admin roles with least‑privilege and justification requirements for admin support access.

4. Operational Readiness
   - Incident management runbooks completed: severity definitions, triage steps, escalation contacts, user communication templates, and status update cadence.
   - Backup/restore drill executed successfully within business RTO/RPO expectations defined in NFRs; outcomes documented.
   - Rollback/disable plan defined at business level: reversible feature toggles or clear revert path available without user‑visible data loss.
   - Capacity and rate‑limit policies exercised via dry runs; system behavior under throttling meets user‑guidance expectations.

5. Documentation and Training
   - Stakeholder review of this acceptance set complete; QA test cases trace to EARS acceptance criteria.
   - User‑facing help content prepared for common tasks and recovery scenarios: registration and verification, login issues, password reset/change, creating and managing todos, completion/reopen, due date/timezone behavior, privacy basics, account deletion, export (if enabled).
   - Internal support playbooks available for first‑line and admin support actions, including session revocation and account suspension/reinstatement.

6. Launch Logistics
   - Launch window scheduled with stakeholder sign‑off, including freeze period and change control policy for the launch week.
   - Pre‑launch dry run executed (day‑in‑the‑life) covering registration‑to‑completion flows with monitoring active; issues resolved.
   - Communication plan finalized (release notes, internal updates) including MVP scope, known limitations, and support contact channels.

### Go/No‑Go Decision Flow (Business View)
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["All Readiness Items Evaluated"] --> B{"All P0/P1 Defects Closed?"}
  B -->|"Yes"| C{"Acceptance Tests Passed?"}
  B -->|"No"| H["No‑Go: Fix Critical Defects"]
  C -->|"Yes"| D{"Monitoring & Support Ready?"}
  C -->|"No"| I["No‑Go: Complete Tests"]
  D -->|"Yes"| E{"Stakeholder Sign‑Off Complete?"}
  D -->|"No"| J["No‑Go: Finalize Ops & Support"]
  E -->|"Yes"| F["Go: Launch Window"]
  E -->|"No"| G["No‑Go: Obtain Approvals"]
```

## 2) MVP Acceptance Criteria (EARS)
Keywords WHEN, WHILE, IF, THEN, WHERE, THE, SHALL remain in English; descriptions are in en‑US.

### 2.1 Authentication and Account Lifecycle
- WHEN a person registers with valid email and password, THE todoApp SHALL create a new account and send an email verification within 1 minute.
- IF a person attempts to register with an email already in use, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject the registration and instruct the person to reset password or use another email.
- WHEN a person verifies the email within 24 hours, THE todoApp SHALL activate the account and allow login.
- IF an email verification link is expired, THEN THE todoApp SHALL present a method to request a new verification link.
- WHEN a user logs in with correct credentials for an active account, THE todoApp SHALL grant access within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- IF a user enters incorrect credentials, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny access and provide actionable guidance to recover (e.g., reset password).
- WHEN a user logs out, THE todoApp SHALL end the active session immediately from the user perspective.
- WHEN a user initiates password reset with a registered email, THE todoApp SHALL send reset instructions within 1 minute.
- IF a password reset token is invalid or expired, THEN THE todoApp SHALL prevent password change and provide a method to request a new reset.
- WHERE an account is suspended by an admin for policy reasons, THE todoApp SHALL prevent access to protected features and communicate suspension status at next sign‑in attempt.
- WHEN a user requests account deletion, THE todoApp SHALL schedule deletion in accordance with data lifecycle requirements and confirm request receipt to the user.
- WHERE a user chooses “revoke all sessions,” THE todoApp SHALL invalidate existing sessions within 60 seconds and require re‑authentication on all devices.

### 2.2 Todo Item Core Operations
- WHEN a logged‑in user submits a new todo with a non‑empty title up to the allowed length, THE todoApp SHALL create the todo and show it in the user’s list immediately.
- IF a user attempts to create a todo without a title or exceeding the maximum length, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject creation and display validation guidance.
- WHEN a user updates title, description, or due date of their own todo with valid values, THE todoApp SHALL persist the changes and reflect them in the list within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- IF a user attempts to update a todo they do not own, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny the action and retain the original state.
- WHEN a user marks their own todo as complete, THE todoApp SHALL set the completion state and update list indicators within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- WHEN a user reopens a completed todo, THE todoApp SHALL remove the completion state and update the list accordingly within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- WHEN a user deletes their own todo, THE todoApp SHALL remove it from the list and confirm deletion within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- IF a user attempts to delete a todo they do not own, THEN THE todoApp SHALL deny the action and provide an ownership restriction message.

### 2.3 Filtering, Sorting, and Timezone Behaviors
- WHEN a user filters todos by status (all, active, completed), THE todoApp SHALL return a filtered list consistent with the selected status within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- WHEN a user sorts todos by created time or due date, THE todoApp SHALL present results ordered according to the selected sort within 2 seconds perceived by the user.
- WHILE a user’s timezone preference is set, THE todoApp SHALL display due dates and times in that timezone consistently in lists and details.
- IF a due date is provided without time, THEN THE todoApp SHALL interpret it as end‑of‑day in the user’s timezone.
- IF a due date is invalid or in an unsupported format from the user’s perspective, THEN THE todoApp SHALL reject it and provide clear correction guidance.

### 2.4 Data Ownership, Privacy, and Export
- THE todoApp SHALL restrict todos so that users can view and modify only their own items.
- IF an unauthenticated person attempts to access protected todo features, THEN THE todoApp SHALL require authentication before continuing.
- WHERE an admin needs to assist for support or policy enforcement, THE todoApp SHALL allow admin‑level access to the minimum necessary information for the task and log the access for audit.
- WHEN a user requests export of their todo data (if enabled in MVP), THE todoApp SHALL provide a complete, human‑readable or machine‑readable export within a timeframe communicated to the user and within 24 hours under normal conditions.

### 2.5 Error Handling and Recovery (Business View)
- IF an operation fails due to validation errors, THEN THE todoApp SHALL not change data and SHALL present actionable messages enabling the user to correct and retry immediately.
- IF an operation fails due to conflicting concurrent updates on the same todo, THEN THE todoApp SHALL preserve data integrity and inform the user how to proceed (e.g., refresh to load the latest and reapply changes).
- IF a temporary service issue prevents completion of a core action, THEN THE todoApp SHALL encourage retry and avoid duplicate creations or updates from a single user action.
- IF a rate limit is reached, THEN THE todoApp SHALL inform the user in natural language and indicate when they may try again.

### 2.6 Performance and Responsiveness
- THE todoApp SHALL complete core interactions (login, list load, add, edit, complete, delete, filter/sort) within 2 seconds perceived by the user for the 95th percentile under expected MVP load.
- WHERE larger lists are present (e.g., 500 todos), THE todoApp SHALL allow the user to access and interact with a subset without undue delay and provide a predictable way to navigate additional items.
- WHERE a bulk action affects up to 50 items, THE todoApp SHALL complete the action within targets set in NFRs or process asynchronously with clear notification.

### 2.7 Administration (Business Controls)
- WHEN an admin suspends an account for policy reasons, THE todoApp SHALL prevent further protected actions by that account and record the action for audit.
- WHEN an admin reinstates a suspended account, THE todoApp SHALL restore access to protected features.
- WHEN an admin needs to view a user’s account for support, THE todoApp SHALL limit visibility to the minimum necessary data and record the access for audit.
- WHEN an admin revokes a user’s sessions, THE todoApp SHALL require the user to sign in again on subsequent actions and record the event for audit.

### 2.8 Audit and Activity Logging (Acceptance)
- THE todoApp SHALL record business‑relevant audit entries for: registration, email verification, login success/failure, logout, password reset request/completion, password change, session creation/refresh/revocation, account suspension/reactivation, account deletion request/completion, admin support access to user data, and modification of more than 20 items in a bulk action.
- WHEN an audit event is recorded, THE todoApp SHALL capture event type, actor role (user/admin), timestamp (UTC), target (where relevant), outcome (success/failure), and justification (where required) without storing sensitive secrets.

## 3) Post‑Launch Monitoring Plan (Business‑Level)
Monitoring begins day 0 and relies on dashboards accessible to stakeholders; thresholds initiate incident processes.

1. Availability and Performance (User‑Perceived)
   - Track success percentage of core actions: login, list, create, update, complete, delete.
   - Track p95 completion time for core actions; target ≤ 2 seconds; track p99 for regression signals.
   - Track error rate by category: authentication failures, authorization denials, validation errors, conflicts, rate‑limit denials, temporary service issues.
   - Track read‑after‑write visibility latency and cross‑device propagation latency per NFR targets.

2. Adoption and Engagement
   - New accounts per day and percentage verified within 24 hours.
   - Time‑to‑first‑todo: median ≤ 5 minutes; distribution by cohort.
   - DAU/WAU/MAU with week‑over‑week growth; engagement distribution across create, update, complete actions.
   - Task completion ratio: completed/created per cohort; overdue ratio.

3. Data Quality and Privacy Indicators
   - Ownership violations prevented (successful violations must be zero); denials are counted as attempts and triaged if anomalous.
   - Admin support accesses with justification logs; outliers flagged for review.
   - Export delivery success within target windows; export volume trends.

4. Stability and Support Load
   - Support contacts per 1,000 active users per week; first‑contact resolution rate.
   - Top 5 user‑reported issues and time‑to‑resolution; recurring themes tracked.
   - Incident count and duration by severity; availability vs. SLO error budget.

Alerting Thresholds (Business View)
- WHEN p95 completion time for any core action exceeds 2 seconds for 15 continuous minutes, THE operations process SHALL initiate an incident response and prioritize restoration to target performance.
- WHEN success rate of any core action drops below 99% for 15 continuous minutes, THE operations process SHALL begin investigation and user communication steps.
- WHEN verification completion within 24 hours drops below 80% for 2 consecutive days, THE product process SHALL review onboarding guidance and friction points.
- WHEN rate‑limit denials spike above 2% of attempts in a 10‑minute window, THE product process SHALL evaluate guidance and potential abuse patterns.

## 4) User Satisfaction and Support Plan
1. Feedback Collection
   - In‑product lightweight CSAT prompt for key actions (create/complete todo) shown non‑intrusively after completion, no more than once per 30 days per user.
   - Quarterly NPS and qualitative survey to verified users; open‑ended improvement prompts collected and categorized.
   - Feedback channels: help center form and dedicated email monitored during business hours; triage categorization aligned to error taxonomy.

2. Support SLAs (Business Commitments)
   - Severity 1 (core actions unavailable for many users): acknowledgement within 15 minutes; user‑facing update every 60 minutes until resolution.
   - Severity 2 (significant degradation or feature impairment): acknowledgement within 2 business hours; updates every business day until resolution.
   - Severity 3 (minor issues or guidance requests): acknowledgement within 2 business days; resolution targeted within 5 business days.
   - Post‑incident summaries for Sev‑1/Sev‑2 incidents circulated within 5 business days, including user impact and prevention actions.

3. Knowledge and Enablement
   - Self‑service articles: account creation/verification, login troubleshooting, password reset/change, creating/managing todos, completion/reopen, due date/timezone semantics, privacy/data lifecycle, account deletion, export.
   - Internal playbooks: admin session revocation and account suspension/reinstatement with justification logging.

4. Launch Support Posture
   - First 2 weeks: extended support window and increased staffing; proactive monitoring of onboarding funnel and verification completion.
   - Communication templates ready for common errors and incidents; tone consistent and user‑centric.

## 5) Success Metrics and Reporting Cadence
Targets for the first 90 days post‑launch; ambitious yet feasible for MVP.

1. Activation and Onboarding
   - Email verification completion within 24 hours ≥ 85% by day 30; ≥ 90% by day 90.
   - Time‑to‑first‑todo median ≤ 5 minutes by day 30; ≤ 3 minutes by day 90.

2. Engagement
   - D7 retention ≥ 25% by day 30; ≥ 30% by day 90.
   - Task completion ratio (completed/created) ≥ 70% by day 30; ≥ 75% by day 90.
   - Median todos created per active user per week ≥ 5 by day 90.

3. Satisfaction and Support
   - CSAT on key actions ≥ 4.3/5 by day 30; ≥ 4.5/5 by day 90.
   - NPS ≥ +20 by quarter end.
   - Support contacts ≤ 10 per 1,000 active users per week by day 30; ≤ 7 by day 90; first‑contact resolution ≥ 70% by day 90.

4. Reliability and Performance (User‑Perceived)
   - p95 completion time for core actions ≤ 2 seconds sustained.
   - Core action success rate ≥ 99.5% sustained (excluding user‑initiated validation denials).
   - Zero Sev‑1 incidents in the first 14 days; ≤ 1 Sev‑1 and ≤ 3 Sev‑2 incidents by day 90.

Reporting Cadence
- Weekly: activation, engagement, reliability summary with deltas vs. targets and top issues; action items for the next week.
- Monthly: cohort analysis, retention and satisfaction trends, export usage, and prioritized improvements.
- Quarterly: strategic review against Service Overview KPIs and recommendations for roadmap adjustments.

## 6) Risks and Mitigations
Major risks relevant to acceptance and sustained success with business mitigations.

1. Performance Risk (User‑Perceived Latency)
   - Risk: Perceived delays above 2 seconds degrade satisfaction and retention.
   - Mitigation: Performance budget tracking; phased exposure if needed; prioritize optimization of list load and write actions; temporarily disable non‑critical features during incidents to preserve core actions.

2. Onboarding Friction
   - Risk: Low email verification rates and complex password resets reduce activation.
   - Mitigation: Clear messaging for verification; resend link flow; simple reset guidance; monitor verification funnel and test copy improvements.

3. Data Integrity and Concurrency Conflicts
   - Risk: Lost updates or conflicting edits cause user confusion.
   - Mitigation: Conflict detection behaviors and user guidance; encourage refresh and reapply; emphasize integrity in acceptance tests.

4. Privacy and Access Control
   - Risk: Improper access to another user’s data erodes trust.
   - Mitigation: Strict ownership rules, minimum‑necessary admin access with justification, and audit expectations; periodic review of admin support accesses.

5. Support Overload at Launch
   - Risk: High contact volume overwhelms support.
   - Mitigation: Proactive FAQ, clear in‑product guidance for common errors, temporary extended support during first 2 weeks, incident communication templates prepared.

6. Scope Creep Before Go‑Live
   - Risk: Unplanned features jeopardize schedule and quality.
   - Mitigation: Enforce MVP scope freeze; redirect additions to post‑MVP backlog with business justification.

7. Insufficient Monitoring or Alert Fatigue
   - Risk: Missed issues or slow response to degradations.
   - Mitigation: Focus alerts on user‑perceived metrics (success rate, p95 time); define actionable thresholds; tune based on signal‑to‑noise.

8. Legal/Compliance Changes
   - Risk: Regulatory changes or regional policies affect privacy, retention, or consent.
   - Mitigation: Periodic policy reviews; update notices and flows; maintain documented exceptions (e.g., legal hold) as business rules.

9. Dependency Outages
   - Risk: Email delivery or other third‑party services degrade onboarding or recovery flows.
   - Mitigation: Transparent user messaging and retry guidance; contingency plans for delayed emails; operational escalation with providers.

---

## Traceability to Acceptance and Success
- Each acceptance criterion maps to features in the [todoApp Functional Requirements](./03-todoApp-functional-requirements.md) and quality targets in the [todoApp Non‑Functional Requirements](./08-todoApp-non-functional-requirements.md).
- Release readiness, monitoring, and KPI targets align with the go‑to‑market plan and KPIs in the [todoApp Service Overview](./01-todoApp-service-overview.md).

End of document.

models.name: todoapp_service_settings
models.description: Platform-wide service settings scoped by deployment environment. Defines global operational defaults such as time zone, token/session lifetimes, rate limits, retention windows, and other guardrails used across services. Configuration is read by application services; no direct FK dependencies to business tables to avoid circular coupling.

plainFields.name: environment
plainFields.description: Deployment environment identifier (e.g., development, staging, production). Used to scope settings uniquely per environment.

plainFields.name: default_time_zone
plainFields.description: Default IANA time zone used when a user profile has no preference. Example: Asia/Seoul.

plainFields.name: session_max_concurrent
plainFields.description: Maximum number of concurrently active sessions per user account (business default: 10).

plainFields.name: access_token_ttl_minutes
plainFields.description: Access token validity duration in minutes (business default: 20).

plainFields.name: refresh_token_ttl_days
plainFields.description: Refresh token validity duration in days (business default: 30).

plainFields.name: session_inactivity_ttl_days
plainFields.description: Days of inactivity after which a session expires (business default: 30).

plainFields.name: reauth_required_minutes
plainFields.description: Minutes defining the recent re-authentication window required for sensitive actions (business default: 15).

plainFields.name: email_verification_token_ttl_hours
plainFields.description: Email verification token validity in hours (business default: 24).

plainFields.name: password_reset_token_ttl_minutes
plainFields.description: Password reset token validity in minutes (business default: 60).

plainFields.name: login_failure_threshold
plainFields.description: Number of failed login attempts allowed within the policy window before cooldown applies (business default: 10).

plainFields.name: login_cooldown_minutes
plainFields.description: Cooldown duration in minutes after exceeding login failure threshold (business default: 5).

plainFields.name: write_ops_per_minute
plainFields.description: Per-account write operations per minute allowed before throttling (business default: 60).

plainFields.name: read_ops_per_minute
plainFields.description: Per-account read operations per minute allowed before throttling (business default: 120).

plainFields.name: bulk_action_item_limit
plainFields.description: Maximum number of items permitted in a single interactive bulk operation (business default: 50).

plainFields.name: trash_retention_days
plainFields.description: Number of days items remain in soft-deleted state before automatic purge (business default: 30).

plainFields.name: account_deletion_grace_days
plainFields.description: Grace period in days before permanent account deletion after user-initiated request (business default: 14).

plainFields.name: unverified_account_purge_days
plainFields.description: Number of days after which unverified accounts are purged if not verified (business default: 14).

plainFields.name: export_sla_hours
plainFields.description: Target hours within which user data exports should be made available under normal conditions (business default: 24).

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Record creation timestamp.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Record last update timestamp.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp. Null when active.

Policies include minimum length, character class requirements, banned password list version, and reuse-prevention window. Application logic selects an active policy by name; no direct FK dependencies to user entities.

plainFields.name: name

plainFields.name: min_length

plainFields.name: require_uppercase

plainFields.name: require_lowercase

plainFields.name: require_numbers

plainFields.name: require_special

plainFields.name: banned_passwords_version

plainFields.name: prevent_last_n_reuse

plainFields.name: description

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Record creation timestamp.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Record last update timestamp.

plainFields.name: deleted_at

models.name: todoapp_maintenance_windows
models.description: Planned maintenance or read-only windows scoped per environment. Supports one-off or recurring schedules via a string RRULE. Used by operations to communicate downtime and by services to apply protective modes. Status-based retrieval is common during operations dashboards.

plainFields.name: environment

plainFields.name: code

plainFields.name: title

plainFields.name: description

plainFields.name: starts_at

plainFields.name: ends_at
plainFields.description: Scheduled end timestamp (UTC).

plainFields.name: recurring
plainFields.description: Whether the maintenance window recurs on a schedule.

plainFields.name: recurrence_rule
plainFields.description: Recurrence rule (e.g., RRULE) when recurring=true; stored as string for portability.

plainFields.name: status
plainFields.description: Lifecycle status label (e.g., scheduled, in_progress, completed, canceled).

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Record creation timestamp.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Record last update timestamp.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp. Null when active.

models.name: todoapp_feature_flags
models.description: Environment-scoped feature toggles controlling conditional behavior across services. Flags include on/off state, optional progressive rollout, and optional targeting rules serialized as string. Read-heavy usage patterns require fast retrieval of enabled flags per environment.

plainFields.name: environment
plainFields.description: Deployment environment this flag applies to (e.g., staging, production).

plainFields.name: key
plainFields.description: Feature flag key (programmatic identifier). Unique within the same environment.

plainFields.name: description
plainFields.description: Human-readable description of the flag’s purpose and scope.

plainFields.name: enabled
plainFields.description: Whether the feature is globally enabled for this environment.

plainFields.name: rollout_percentage
plainFields.description: Progressive rollout percentage (0–100) for gradual enablement; applications interpret this according to targeting strategy.

plainFields.name: targeting_rules
plainFields.description: Optional serialized targeting criteria (e.g., JSON or DSL) for audience-based rollout. Stored as string for portability.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Record creation timestamp.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Record last update timestamp.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp. Null when active.

models.name: todoapp_accounts
models.description: Primary account entity representing a unique identity within todoApp. Stores authentication credential artifacts (hashed password), email address, and verification state. Acts as the anchor for role assignments via {@link todoapp_users} and {@link todoapp_admins}, for sessions via {@link todoapp_sessions}, and for short-lived artifacts in {@link todoapp_email_verifications} and {@link todoapp_password_resets}. Follows least-privilege principles by keeping profile and preference data outside of this table.

plainFields.name: email
plainFields.description: Unique email address for the account. Used for authentication and recovery communications. Case-insensitive uniqueness enforced by business logic.

plainFields.name: password_hash
plainFields.description: Argon2/bcrypt or similar password hash. Never stores raw passwords. Used exclusively for credential verification.

plainFields.name: email_verified
plainFields.description: Whether the account’s email has been verified. Governs access to sensitive actions per policy.

plainFields.name: status
plainFields.description: Business status of the account (e.g., active, suspended, deletion_pending). Used for access control and lifecycle workflows.

plainFields.name: last_login_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of the most recent successful login for user-facing security history and anomaly detection.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Creation timestamp of the account record.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last update timestamp of the account record.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp. When set, the account is logically deleted and excluded from normal operations.

models.name: todoapp_users
models.description: Role assignment table for standard end users. Represents the "user" role bound 1:1 to an {@link todoapp_accounts} record. Keeps role membership separate from credentials for least-privilege and clear authorization boundaries.

foreignFields.name: todoapp_account_id
foreignFields.description: Owning account’s {@link todoapp_accounts.id}. Establishes a 1:1 mapping between account and user role.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Creation timestamp of the user role record.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last update timestamp of the user role record.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp for role revocation without physical removal.

models.name: todoapp_admins
models.description: Role assignment table for administrative users operating under least‑privilege with audit. Represents the "admin" role bound 1:1 to an {@link todoapp_accounts} record. Separation from credentials and user content enables strict access governance and auditing.

foreignFields.name: todoapp_account_id
foreignFields.description: Owning account’s {@link todoapp_accounts.id}. Establishes a 1:1 mapping between account and admin role.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Creation timestamp of the admin role record.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last update timestamp of the admin role record.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp for role revocation without physical removal.

models.name: todoapp_user_profiles
models.description: End-user profile and personalization data separated from credentials. Bound 1:1 with {@link todoapp_accounts}. Stores display preferences such as display name, locale, and time zone. Used by application layers to render dates in the user’s local time while keeping authentication data isolated.

foreignFields.name: todoapp_account_id
foreignFields.description: Profile owner account’s {@link todoapp_accounts.id}. Ensures exactly one profile per account.

plainFields.name: display_name
plainFields.description: User’s display name for UI. Does not affect authentication. Optional and can be changed by the user.

plainFields.name: locale
plainFields.description: Preferred locale tag (e.g., en-US). Guides language and formatting in the UI.

plainFields.name: time_zone
plainFields.description: IANA time zone identifier (e.g., Asia/Seoul). Used to interpret and display date/time fields.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Creation timestamp of the profile record.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last update timestamp of the profile record.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp. When set, the profile is considered inactive.

models.name: todoapp_sessions
models.description: Authentication session records bound to {@link todoapp_accounts}. Enables session listing, selective revocation, and device-level tracking in alignment with rotating refresh-token policy. Stores only raw session metadata (e.g., hashed refresh token); no calculated fields. Optional link to {@link todoapp_device_labels} for user-managed device names (existing in another component).

foreignFields.name: todoapp_account_id
foreignFields.description: Session owner account’s {@link todoapp_accounts.id}.

foreignFields.name: todoapp_device_label_id
foreignFields.description: Optional device label’s {@link todoapp_device_labels.id} for user-provided device names. Reference-only: table already exists in another component.

plainFields.name: device_key
plainFields.description: Stable device/session key for listing and selective revocation (e.g., fingerprint or generated key).

plainFields.name: refresh_token_hash
plainFields.description: Rotating refresh token hash tied to this session. Stored as a hash; unique to prevent reuse.

plainFields.name: user_agent
plainFields.description: Client user-agent string captured at session creation for security visibility.

plainFields.name: ip
plainFields.description: Coarse IP string captured for security and session listing. Precision governed by policy.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Creation timestamp of the session (login time).

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last update timestamp of the session record.

plainFields.name: last_activity_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of the most recent activity observed for this session.

plainFields.name: expires_at
plainFields.description: Absolute expiry time for the session or refresh token validity window.

plainFields.name: revoked_at
plainFields.description: When set, indicates the session was explicitly revoked and is no longer valid.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp for administrative cleanup or retention policy enforcement.

models.name: todoapp_email_verifications

plainFields.name: token_hash

plainFields.name: sent_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp when the verification message was dispatched.

plainFields.name: expires_at
plainFields.description: Expiry time after which the token is no longer valid.

plainFields.name: verified_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp when the verification succeeded. Null until completed.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Creation timestamp of the verification artifact.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last update timestamp of the verification artifact.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft deletion timestamp for administrative cleanup when artifacts are removed before natural expiry.

models.name: todoapp_password_resets
models.description: Short-lived artifacts for password reset flows scoped to {@link todoapp_accounts}. Stores hashed tokens and lifecycle timestamps to support secure resets, rotation, and audit without retaining sensitive secrets.

foreignFields.name: todoapp_account_id
foreignFields.description: Target account’s {@link todoapp_accounts.id} for which the password reset is requested.

plainFields.name: token_hash
plainFields.description: Password reset token hash. Raw tokens are never stored. Used to validate reset requests.

plainFields.name: requested_at
